children.name: Counting And Cardinality
Know Number Names And The Count Sequence.

data.description: Count to 100 by ones and by tens.

khanAcademyContent.name: Numbers to 100
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice finding missing numbers in a list of numbers between 0 and 100.

khanAcademyContent.name: Count tens
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice counting by tens.

data.description: Count forward beginning from a given number within the known sequence (instead of having to begin at 1).

khanAcademyContent.name: Missing numbers
khanAcademyContent.description: Find the missing number in a list of numbers. Numbers used are 20 or less.

data.description: Write numbers from 0 to 20. Represent a number of objects with a written numeral 0-20 (with 0 representing a count of no objects).

children.name: Count To Tell The Number Of Objects.

data.description: When counting objects, say the number names in the standard order, pairing each object with one and only one number name and each number name with one and only one object.
Understand that the last number name said tells the number of objects counted. The number of objects is the same regardless of their arrangement or the order in which they were counted.
Understand that each successive number name refers to a quantity that is one larger.
Understand the relationship between numbers and quantities; connect counting to cardinality.

khanAcademyContent.name: Count in order
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice counting without making mistakes.

khanAcademyContent.name: Find 1 more or 1 less than a number
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice finding one more or one less than a number.

khanAcademyContent.name: Count in pictures
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice counting objects in pictures.

data.description: Count to answer “how many?” questions about as many as 20 things arranged in a line, a rectangular array, or a circle, or as many as 10 things in a scattered configuration; given a number from 1–20, count out that many objects.

khanAcademyContent.name: Count objects 2
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice counting up to 20 objects in random patterns.

khanAcademyContent.name: Count with small numbers
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice counting up to 10 objects.

khanAcademyContent.name: Count objects 1
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice counting up to 20 objects. Objects are organized neatly into rows and columns.

children.name: Compare Numbers.

data.description:
Identify whether the number of objects in one group is greater than, less than, or equal to the number of objects in another group, e.g., by using matching and counting strategies.*

* Include groups with up to ten objects.

khanAcademyContent.name: Compare numbers of objects 1
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice counting which group has more objects.

data.description: Compare two numbers between 1 and 10 presented as written numerals.

khanAcademyContent.name: Comparing numbers to 10
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice saying if one number is less than or greater than another number. Numbers are between 0 and 10.

children.name: Geometry
Identify And Describe Shapes (Squares, Circles, Triangles, Rectangles, Hexagons, Cubes, Cones, Cylinders, And Spheres).

data.description: Describe objects in the environment using names of shapes, and describe the relative positions of these objects using terms such as above, below, beside, in front of, behind, and next to.

khanAcademyContent.name: Name shapes 1
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice identifying circles, triangles, squares, and rectangles.

khanAcademyContent.name: Relative position
khanAcademyContent.description: Decide if objects are above, below, beside, in front of, or behind other objects.

data.description: Correctly name shapes regardless of their orientations or overall size.

khanAcademyContent.name: Name shapes 2
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice more challenging problems identifying circles, triangles, squares, and rectangles.

data.description: Identify shapes as two-dimensional (lying in a plane, “flat”) or three- dimensional (“solid”).

children.name: Analyze, Compare, Create, And Compose Shapes.

data.description: Analyze and compare two- and three-dimensional shapes, in different sizes and orientations, using informal language to describe their similarities, differences, parts (e.g., number of sides and vertices/“corners”) and other attributes (e.g., having sides of equal length).

khanAcademyContent.name: Compare shapes
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice comparing shapes based on their number of sides, number of corners, and side-lengths.

data.description: Model shapes in the world by building shapes from components (e.g., sticks and clay balls) and drawing shapes.
Compose simple shapes to form larger shapes. For example, “Can you join these two triangles with full sides touching to make a rectangle?”

khanAcademyContent.name: Compose shapes
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice combining shapes to make other shapes.

children.name: Measurement And Data
Describe And Compare Measurable Attributes.

data.description: Describe measurable attributes of objects, such as length or weight. Describe several measurable attributes of a single object.

Directly compare two objects with a measurable attribute in common, to see which object has “more of”/“less of” the attribute, and describe the difference. For example, directly compare the heights of two children and describe one child as taller/shorter.

khanAcademyContent.name: Compare size
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice comparing 2 objects to see which is bigger, smaller, taller, shorter, or longer.

children.name: Classify Objects And Count The Number Of Objects In Each Category.

data.description:
Classify objects into given categories; count the numbers of objects in each category and sort the categories by count.*

*Limit category counts to be less than or equal to 10.

khanAcademyContent.name: Compare numbers of objects 2
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice counting to see which group has the most things in it.

children.name: Number And Operations In Base Ten
Work With Numbers 11–19 To Gain Foundations For Place Value.

data.description: Compose and decompose numbers from 11 to 19 into ten ones and some further ones, e.g., by using objects or drawings, and record each composition or decomposition by a drawing or equation (e.g., 18 = 10 + 8); understand that these numbers are composed of ten ones and one, two, three, four, five, six, seven, eight, or nine ones.

khanAcademyContent.name: Teen numbers
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice thinking of teen numbers as a ten plus some ones.

children.name: Operations And Algebraic Thinking
Understand Addition As Putting Together And Adding To, And Under- Stand Subtraction As Taking Apart And Taking From.

data.description:
Represent addition and subtraction with objects, fingers, mental images, drawings*, sounds (e.g., claps), acting out situations, verbal explanations, expressions, or equations.

*Drawings need not show details, but should show the mathematics in the problem. (This applies wherever drawings are mentioned in the Standards.)

khanAcademyContent.name: Subtract within 10
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice subtracting by "taking apart" (with numbers less than 10).

khanAcademyContent.name: Add within 10
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice adding by "putting together" (with numbers less than 10).

data.description: Solve addition and subtraction word problems, and add and subtract within 10, e.g., by using objects or drawings to represent the problem.

khanAcademyContent.name: Subtraction word problems within 10
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice solving word problems by subtracting small numbers (numbers 10 or less).

khanAcademyContent.name: Addition word problems within 10
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice solving word problems by adding small numbers (numbers 10 or less).

data.description: Decompose numbers less than or equal to 10 into pairs in more than one way, e.g., by using objects or drawings, and record each decomposition by a drawing or equation (e.g., 5 = 2 + 3 and 5 = 4 + 1).

khanAcademyContent.name: Making small numbers in different ways
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice making a number by adding other numbers. All numbers in these problems are less than 10.

data.description: For any number from 1 to 9, find the number that makes 10 when added to the given number, e.g., by using objects or drawings, and record the answer with a drawing or equation.

khanAcademyContent.name: Making 5
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice adding numbers to make 5.

khanAcademyContent.name: Make 10 (grids and number bonds)
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice adding numbers to make 10. These problems show grids to help you out.

khanAcademyContent.name: Make 10
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice adding numbers to make 10.

data.description: Fluently add and subtract within 5.

khanAcademyContent.name: Add within 5
khanAcademyContent.description: Add small numbers. All answers are five or less.

khanAcademyContent.name: Subtract within 5
khanAcademyContent.description: Subtract small numbers. All answers are less than 5.

children.name: Geometry
Reason With Shapes And Their Attributes.

data.description: Distinguish between defining attributes (e.g., triangles are closed and three-sided) versus non-defining attributes (e.g., color, orientation, overall size); build and draw shapes to possess defining attributes.

khanAcademyContent.name: Name shapes 3
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice identifying circles, triangles, squares, rectangles, rhombuses, trapezoids, and hexagons.

data.description:
Compose two-dimensional shapes (rectangles, squares, trapezoids, triangles, half-circles, and quarter-circles) or three-dimensional shapes (cubes, right rectangular prisms, right circular cones, and right circular cylinders) to create a composite shape, and compose new shapes from the composite shape.*

*Students do not need to learn formal names such as “right rectangular prism.”

Partition circles and rectangles into two and four equal shares, describe the shares using the words halves, fourths, and quarters, and use the phrases half of, fourth of, and quarter of. Describe the whole as two of, or four of the shares. Understand for these examples that decomposing into more equal shares creates smaller shares.

khanAcademyContent.name: Halves and fourths
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice dividing shapes into 2 or 4 equal sections.

children.name: Measurement And Data
Measure Lengths Indirectly And By Iterating Length Units.

data.description: Order three objects by length; compare the lengths of two objects indirectly by using a third object.

khanAcademyContent.name: Indirect measurement
khanAcademyContent.description: Compare the lengths of 2 objects indirectly by using a third object.

khanAcademyContent.name: Order by length
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice ordering 3 objects by length.

data.description: Express the length of an object as a whole number of length units, by laying multiple copies of a shorter object (the length unit) end to end; understand that the length measurement of an object is the number of same-size length units that span it with no gaps or overlaps. Limit to contexts where the object being measured is spanned by a whole number of length units with no gaps or overlaps.

khanAcademyContent.name: Measure lengths 1
khanAcademyContent.description: Measure objects with same-size length units without gaps or overlaps.

children.name: Tell And Write Time.

data.description: Tell and write time in hours and half-hours using analog and digital clocks.

khanAcademyContent.name: Tell time to hour or half hour
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice telling time on analog clocks to the hour or half hour.

children.name: Represent And Interpret Data.

data.description: Organize, represent, and interpret data with up to three categories; ask and answer questions about the total number of data points, how many in each category, and how many more or less are in one category than in another.

khanAcademyContent.name: Solve problems with bar graphs 1
khanAcademyContent.description: Read and interpret bar graphs.

children.name: Number And Operations In Base Ten
Extend The Counting Sequence.

data.description: Count to 120, starting at any number less than 120. In this range, read and write numerals and represent a number of objects with a written numeral.

khanAcademyContent.name: Numbers to 120
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice finding missing numbers in a list of numbers between 0 and 120.

children.name: Understand Place Value.

data.description: 10 can be thought of as a bundle of ten ones — called a “ten.” b.
The numbers from 11 to 19 are composed of a ten and one, two, three, four, five, six, seven, eight, or nine ones.
The numbers 10, 20, 30, 40, 50, 60, 70, 80, 90 refer to one, two, three, four, five, six, seven, eight, or nine tens (and 0 ones).
Understand that the two digits of a two-digit number represent amounts of tens and ones. Understand the following as special cases:

khanAcademyContent.name: Groups of ten objects
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice grouping objects by tens.

khanAcademyContent.name: 2-digit place value challenge
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice breaking numbers apart into tens and ones.

data.description: Compare two two-digit numbers based on meanings of the tens and ones digits, recording the results of comparisons with the symbols >, =, and <.

khanAcademyContent.name: Compare 2-digit numbers 2
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice more challenging problems comparing numbers within 100.

khanAcademyContent.name: Compare 2-digit numbers
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice comparing numbers (within 100) using the symbols <, >, and =.

children.name: Use Place Value Understanding And Properties Of Operations To Add And Subtract.

data.description: Add within 100, including adding a two-digit number and a one-digit number, and adding a two-digit number and a multiple of 10, using concrete models or drawings and strategies based on place value, properties of operations, and/or the relationship between addition and subtraction; relate the strategy to a written method and explain the reasoning used. Understand that in adding two-digit numbers, one adds tens and tens, ones and ones; and sometimes it is necessary to compose a ten.

khanAcademyContent.name: Break apart 2-digit addition problems
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice breaking apart problems like 23+45 into problems like 20+40+3+5.

khanAcademyContent.name: Add 1 or 10
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice solving problems like 34+1 and 34+10.

khanAcademyContent.name: Add 2-digit numbers (no regrouping)
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice solving problems like 24 + 45.

khanAcademyContent.name: Add 1s or 10s (no regrouping)
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice solving problems like 34+5 and 34+50.

khanAcademyContent.name: Regroup when adding 1-digit numbers
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice adding numbers like 45+8.

data.description: Given a two-digit number, mentally find 10 more or 10 less than the number, without having to count; explain the reasoning used.

khanAcademyContent.name: Add 1 or 10
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice solving problems like 34+1 and 34+10.

data.description: Subtract multiples of 10 in the range 10-90 from multiples of 10 in the range 10-90 (positive or zero differences), using concrete models or drawings and strategies based on place value, properties of operations, and/or the relationship between addition and subtraction; relate the strategy to a written method and explain the reasoning used.

children.name: Operations And Algebraic Thinking
Represent And Solve Problems Involving Addition And Subtraction.

data.description:
Use addition and subtraction within 20 to solve word problems involving situations of adding to, taking from, putting together, taking apart, and comparing, with unknowns in all positions, e.g., by using objects, drawings, and equations with a symbol for the unknown number to represent the problem.*

*See Glossary, Table 1.

khanAcademyContent.name: Addition and subtraction word problems 2
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice solving more challenging word problems with addition and subtraction. Numbers used are 20 or less.

khanAcademyContent.name: Word problems with "more" and "fewer" 2
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice solving more word problems by finding how many more (or fewer) objects there are. Numbers used are 20 or less.

khanAcademyContent.name: Word problems with "more" and "fewer" 1
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice solving word problems by finding how many more (or fewer) objects there are. Numbers used are 20 or less.

khanAcademyContent.name: Addition and subtraction word problems 1
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice adding and subtracting to solve word problems. Numbers used are 20 or less.

khanAcademyContent.name: Word problems with "more" and "fewer
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice solving word problems by finding how many more (or fewer) objects there are. Each problem shows a diagram to help you.

data.description: Solve word problems that call for addition of three whole numbers whose sum is less than or equal to 20, e.g., by using objects, drawings, and equations with a symbol for the unknown number to represent the problem.

khanAcademyContent.name: Add 3 numbers
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice adding 3 numbers. All numbers in these problems are 20 or less.

children.name: Understand And Apply Properties Of Operations And The Relationship Between Addition And Subtraction.

data.description:
Apply properties of operations as strategies to add and subtract.* Examples: If 8 + 3 = 11 is known, then 3 + 8 = 11 is also known. (Commutative property of addition.) To add 2 + 6 + 4, the second two numbers can be added to make a ten, so 2 + 6 + 4 = 2 + 10 = 12. (Associative property of addition.)

*Students need not use formal terms for these properties.
Understand subtraction as an unknown-addend problem. For example, subtract 10 – 8 by finding the number that makes 10 when added to 8.

khanAcademyContent.name: Relate addition and subtraction
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice seeing how addition and subtraction are related.

children.name: Add And Subtract Within 20.

data.description: Relate counting to addition and subtraction (e.g., by counting on 2 to add 2).

Add and subtract within 20, demonstrating fluency for addition and subtraction within 10. Use strategies such as counting on; making ten (e.g., 8 + 6 = 8 + 2 + 4 = 10 + 4 = 14); decomposing a number leading to a ten (e.g., 13 – 4 = 13 – 3 – 1 = 10 – 1 = 9); using the relationship between addition and subtraction (e.g., knowing that 8 + 4 = 12, one knows 12 – 8 = 4); and creating equivalent but easier or known sums (e.g., adding 6 + 7 by creating the known equivalent 6 + 6 + 1 = 12 + 1 = 13).

khanAcademyContent.name: Add within 20
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice adding. All numbers in these problems are 20 or less.

khanAcademyContent.name: Subtract within 20
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice subtracting. All numbers in these problems are 20 or less.

children.name: Work With Addition And Subtraction Equations.

data.description: Understand the meaning of the equal sign, and determine if equations involving addition and subtraction are true or false. For example, which of the following equations are true and which are false? 6 = 6, 7 = 8 – 1, 5 + 2 = 2 + 5, 4 + 1 = 5 + 2.

khanAcademyContent.name: Equal sign
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice telling which equation is true.

data.description: Determine the unknown whole number in an addition or subtraction equation relating three whole numbers. For example, determine the unknown number that makes the equation true in each of the equations 8 + ? = 11, 5 = ? – 3, 6 + 6 = ?.

khanAcademyContent.name: Find missing number (add and subtract within 20)
khanAcademyContent.description: Learn how to solve problems like "___ - 7 = 18" where you don't know one of the values in an addition or subtraction equation.

children.name: Geometry
Reason With Shapes And Their Attributes.

data.description:
Recognize and draw shapes having specified attributes, such as a given number of angles or a given number of equal faces.* Identify triangles, quadrilaterals, pentagons, hexagons, and cubes.

*Sizes are compared directly or visually, not compared by measuring.

khanAcademyContent.name: Name shapes 4
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice identifying quadrilaterals, pentagons, hexagons, and octagons.

data.description: Partition a rectangle into rows and columns of same-size squares and count to find the total number of them.

Partition circles and rectangles into two, three, or four equal shares, describe the shares using the words halves, thirds, half of, a third of, etc., and describe the whole as two halves, three thirds, four fourths. Recognize that equal shares of identical wholes need not have the same shape.

khanAcademyContent.name: Equal parts of circles and rectangles
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice telling if shapes are divided into 2 or 4 equal sections.

children.name: Measurement And Data
Measure And Estimate Lengths In Standard Units.

data.description: Measure the length of an object by selecting and using appropriate tools such as rulers, yardsticks, meter sticks, and measuring tapes.

khanAcademyContent.name: Measure lengths 2
khanAcademyContent.description: Measure objects using a ruler.

data.description: Measure the length of an object twice, using length units of different lengths for the two measurements; describe how the two measurements relate to the size of the unit chosen.
Estimate lengths using units of inches, feet, centimeters, and meters.

khanAcademyContent.name: Estimate lengths
khanAcademyContent.description: Estimate lengths using units of centimeters and meters.

khanAcademyContent.name: Estimate lengths (US Customary units)
khanAcademyContent.description: Estimate lengths using units of inches, feet, and yards.

data.description: Measure to determine how much longer one object is than another, expressing the length difference in terms of a standard length unit.

children.name: Relate Addition And Subtraction To Length.

data.description: Use addition and subtraction within 100 to solve word problems involving lengths that are given in the same units, e.g., by using drawings (such as drawings of rulers) and equations with a symbol for the unknown number to represent the problem.

khanAcademyContent.name: Length word problems
khanAcademyContent.description: Add and subtract lengths to solve word problems.

data.description: Represent whole numbers as lengths from 0 on a number line diagram with equally spaced points corresponding to the numbers 0, 1, 2, ..., and represent whole-number sums and differences within 100 on a number line diagram.

khanAcademyContent.name: Add and subtract on the number line word problems
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice adding and subtracting using the number line. Numbers used are 100 or less.

children.name: Work With Time And Money.

data.description: Tell and write time from analog and digital clocks to the nearest five minutes, using a.m. and p.m.

khanAcademyContent.name: Tell time with a labeled clock
khanAcademyContent.description: Tell time on labeled analog clocks.

khanAcademyContent.name: Tell time without labels
khanAcademyContent.description: Tell time on unlabeled analog clocks.

data.description: Solve word problems involving dollar bills, quarters, dimes, nickels, and pennies, using $ and ¢ symbols appropriately. Example: If you have 2 dimes and 3 pennies, how many cents do you have?

khanAcademyContent.name: Count money (U.S.)
khanAcademyContent.description: Find the total value when given an amount of coins or dollars.

children.name: Represent And Interpret Data.

data.description: Generate measurement data by measuring lengths of several objects to the nearest whole unit, or by making repeated measurements of the same object. Show the measurements by making a line plot, where the horizontal scale is marked off in whole-number units.

khanAcademyContent.name: Make line plots
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice creating line plots (dot plots) from data sets.

khanAcademyContent.name: Make bar graphs 1
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice creating bar graphs (bar charts) from data sets.

khanAcademyContent.name: Make picture graphs 1
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice creating picture graphs (pictographs) from data sets.

khanAcademyContent.name: Solve problems with line plots
khanAcademyContent.description: Answer questions using line plots and data sets.

data.description:
Draw a picture graph and a bar graph (with single-unit scale) to represent a data set with up to four categories. Solve simple put- together, take-apart, and compare problems* using information presented in a bar graph.

*See Glossary, Table 1

khanAcademyContent.name: Solve problems with bar graphs 2
khanAcademyContent.description: Use bar graphs to solve addition and subtraction word problems.

khanAcademyContent.name: Solve problems with picture graphs 1
khanAcademyContent.description: Read and interpret picture graphs.

children.name: Number And Operations In Base Ten
Understand Place Value.

data.description: 100 can be thought of as a bundle of ten tens — called a “hundred.”
The numbers 100, 200, 300, 400, 500, 600, 700, 800, 900 refer to one, two, three, four, five, six, seven, eight, or nine hundreds (and 0 tens and 0 ones).
Understand that the three digits of a three-digit number represent amounts of hundreds, tens, and ones; e.g., 706 equals 7 hundreds, 0 tens, and 6 ones. Understand the following as special cases:

khanAcademyContent.name: Hundreds, tens, and ones
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice thinking about place value of 3-digit numbers as hundreds, tens, and ones.

data.description: Count within 1000; skip-count by 5s, 10s, and 100s.

khanAcademyContent.name: Count money (U.S.)
khanAcademyContent.description: Find the total value when given an amount of coins or dollars.

khanAcademyContent.name: Skip-counting by 100s
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice counting by 100s.

khanAcademyContent.name: Skip-count by 10s
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice counting by 10s.

khanAcademyContent.name: Skip-count by 5s
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice counting by 5s.

data.description: Read and write numbers to 1000 using base-ten numerals, number names, and expanded form.

khanAcademyContent.name: 3-digit place value challenge
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice breaking numbers into hundreds, tens, and ones.

data.description: Compare two three-digit numbers based on meanings of the hundreds, tens, and ones digits, using >, =, and < symbols to record the results of comparisons.

khanAcademyContent.name: Subtract 1-digit numbers with regrouping
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice solving problems like 46-9.

khanAcademyContent.name: Compare 3-digit numbers
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice more challenging problems comparing numbers within 1000.

children.name: Use Place Value Understanding And Properties Of Operations To Add And Subtract.

data.description: Fluently add and subtract within 100 using strategies based on place value, properties of operations, and/or the relationship between addition and subtraction.

khanAcademyContent.name: Add within 100
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice adding two-digit numbers. All numbers in these problems are 100 or less.

khanAcademyContent.name: Add 2-digit numbers by making tens 2
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice adding two-digit numbers by making groups of ten.

khanAcademyContent.name: Subtract within 100
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice subtracting 2-digit numbers.

khanAcademyContent.name: Subtract 1 or 10
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice subtracting 1 or 10 from a 2-digit number (no regrouping).

khanAcademyContent.name: Add 2-digit numbers by making tens
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice adding 2-digit numbers like 43+27 that have sums that are multiples of 10.

khanAcademyContent.name: Subtracting 1s or 10s (no regrouping)
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice solving problems like 67-5 and 67-50.

khanAcademyContent.name: Subtract 2-digit numbers (no regrouping)
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice solving problems like 45 - 24.

data.description: Add up to four two-digit numbers using strategies based on place value and properties of operations.

Add and subtract within 1000, using concrete models or drawings and strategies based on place value, properties of operations, and/or the relationship between addition and subtraction; relate the strategy to a written method. Understand that in adding or subtracting three- digit numbers, one adds or subtracts hundreds and hundreds, tens and tens, ones and ones; and sometimes it is necessary to compose or decompose tens or hundreds.

khanAcademyContent.name: Add 2- and 3-digit numbers (no regrouping)
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice solving problems like 243 + 452.

khanAcademyContent.name: Select strategies for adding within 100
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice telling which strategies work for adding two numbers within 100.

khanAcademyContent.name: Subtract 10s and 100s (no regrouping)
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice subtracting 1, 10, or 100 from a number.

khanAcademyContent.name: Add using groups of 10 and 100
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice making groups of 10 and 100 while adding 3-digit numbers.

khanAcademyContent.name: Add and subtract using a number line
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice adding and subtracting numbers like 54 and 37 using a number line. Numbers used in these problems are all less than 100.

khanAcademyContent.name: Estimate to add and subtract multi-digit whole numbers
khanAcademyContent.description: Use estimation to find a reasonable solution to multi-digit addition and subtraction problems. Numbers are less than or equal to 1000.

khanAcademyContent.name: Break apart 3-digit addition problems
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice breaking apart big addition problems using place value. For example, 234+567 is the same as 200+500+30+60+4+7.

khanAcademyContent.name: Add and subtract on a number line
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice adding and subtracting numbers like 554 and 237 using a number line.  All numbers are less than 1000.

khanAcademyContent.name: Add 10s and 100s (no regrouping)
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice solving problems like 344+20 and 344+200.

khanAcademyContent.name: Subtract 2- and 3-digit numbers (no regrouping)
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice solving problems like 452 + 241.

data.description: Mentally add 10 or 100 to a given number 100–900, and mentally subtract 10 or 100 from a given number 100–900.

Explain why addition and subtraction strategies work, using place value and the properties of operations.*

*Explanations may be supported by drawings or objects.

children.name: Operations And Algebraic Thinking
Represent And Solve Problems Involving Addition And Subtraction.

data.description:
Use addition and subtraction within 100 to solve one- and two-step word problems involving situations of adding to, taking from, putting together, taking apart, and comparing, with unknowns in all positions, e.g., by using drawings and equations with a symbol for the unknown number to represent the problem.*

*See Glossary, Table 1

khanAcademyContent.name: Add and subtract within 100 word problems 2
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice solving word problems with addition and subtraction.   These questions are comparison problems including difference unknown, smaller value unknown, and bigger value unknown.  Numbers used are 100 or less.

khanAcademyContent.name: Add and subtract within 100 word problems 3
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice solving word problems with addition and subtraction.   These questions are start unknown problems including add to and take from problems.  Numbers used are 100 or less.

khanAcademyContent.name: Solve problems with picture graphs 1
khanAcademyContent.description: Read and interpret picture graphs.

khanAcademyContent.name: Length word problems
khanAcademyContent.description: Add and subtract lengths to solve word problems.

khanAcademyContent.name: Find the missing number (add and subtract within 100)
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice solving problems like "___ - 45 = 27" where you have to figure out the missing value in an addition or subtraction equation.

khanAcademyContent.name: Challenging add and subtract word problems (within 100)
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice solving more challenging addition and subtraction word problems with "more" and "fewer".​  Multi-step problems are also included.  Numbers used are 100 or less.

khanAcademyContent.name: Add and subtract within 100 word problems 1
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice adding and subtracting to solve word problems. These questions are result unknown or change unknown problems.  Numbers used are 100 or less.

children.name: Add And Subtract Within 20.

data.description:
Fluently add and subtract within 20 using mental strategies.* By end of Grade 2, know from memory all sums of two one-digit numbers.

*See standard 1.OA.6 for a list of mental strategies.

children.name: Work With Equal Groups Of Objects To Gain Foundations For Multiplication.

data.description: Determine whether a group of objects (up to 20) has an odd or even number of members, e.g., by pairing objects or counting them by 2s; write an equation to express an even number as a sum of two equal addends.
Use addition to find the total number of objects arranged in rectangular arrays with up to 5 rows and up to 5 columns; write an equation to express the total as a sum of equal addends.

khanAcademyContent.name: Repeated addition
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice solving word problems by adding the same number many times.

children.name: Geometry
Reason With Shapes And Their Attributes.

data.description: Understand that shapes in different categories (e.g., rhombuses, rectangles, and others) may share attributes (e.g., having four sides), and that the shared attributes can define a larger category (e.g., quadrilaterals). Recognize rhombuses, rectangles, and squares as examples of quadrilaterals, and draw examples of quadrilaterals that do not belong to any of these subcategories.

khanAcademyContent.name: Categorize quadrilaterals
khanAcademyContent.description: Classify and compare rectangles, rhombuses, and squares.

khanAcademyContent.name: Identify quadrilaterals
khanAcademyContent.description: Identify squares, rectangles, and rhombuses.

data.description: Partition shapes into parts with equal areas. Express the area of each part as a unit fraction of the whole. For example, partition a shape into 4 parts with equal area, and describe the area of each part as 1/4 of the area of the shape.

khanAcademyContent.name: Cut shapes into equal parts
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice telling if a shape has been divided into equal parts.

khanAcademyContent.name: Identify unit fractions
khanAcademyContent.description: Identify unit fractions when given a visual or a context.

children.name: Measurement And Data
Solve Problems Involving Measurement And Estimation Of Intervals Of Time, Liquid Volumes, And Masses Of Objects.

data.description: Tell and write time to the nearest minute and measure time intervals in minutes. Solve word problems involving addition and subtraction of time intervals in minutes, e.g., by representing the problem on a number line diagram.

khanAcademyContent.name: Time word problems with number line
khanAcademyContent.description: Use a number line to solving time word problems.

khanAcademyContent.name: Telling time on the number line
khanAcademyContent.description: Match time of a number line to time on an analog or digital clock. Graph a given time on a number line.

khanAcademyContent.name: Time differences (within the hour)
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice finding the difference between times given on two analog clocks. Each time difference is less than 60 minutes, and the hour hand stays on the same hour.

khanAcademyContent.name: Telling time word problems (within the hour)
khanAcademyContent.description: Solve a word problem to find the duration of an event.  Both analog or digital clocks are included.

khanAcademyContent.name: Tell time to the nearest minute
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice telling time using analog clocks. Some clocks do not have labels.

data.description:
Measure and estimate liquid volumes and masses of objects using standard units of grams (g), kilograms (kg), and liters (l).* Add, subtract, multiply, or divide to solve one-step word problems involving masses or volumes that are given in the same units, e.g., by using drawings (such as a beaker with a measurement scale) to represent the problem.**

*Excludes compound units such as cm3 and finding the geometric volume of a container.

**Excludes multiplicative comparison problems (problems involving notions of “times as much”; see Glossary, Table 2)

khanAcademyContent.name: Word problems with volume
khanAcademyContent.description: Solve word problems involving volume.  Estimate the volume of items.

khanAcademyContent.name: Estimate mass (grams and kilograms)
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice estimating the mass of real life objects using grams and kilograms.

khanAcademyContent.name: Estimate volume (milliliters and liters)
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice estimating the volume of real life objects using milliliters and liters.

khanAcademyContent.name: Word problems with mass
khanAcademyContent.description: Solve word problems involving mass.  Estimate the mass of items.

children.name: Represent And Interpret Data.

data.description: Draw a scaled picture graph and a scaled bar graph to represent a data set with several categories. Solve one- and two-step “how many more” and “how many less” problems using information presented in scaled bar graphs. For example, draw a bar graph in which each square in the bar graph might represent 5 pets.

khanAcademyContent.name: Create bar graphs
khanAcademyContent.description: Create a bar graph with the data given.

khanAcademyContent.name: Create picture graphs (picture more than 1)
khanAcademyContent.description: Create and interpret picture graphs.

khanAcademyContent.name: Read bar graphs and solve 2 step problems
khanAcademyContent.description: Read and interpret a double bar graphs.

khanAcademyContent.name: Read bar graphs and solve 1-step problems
khanAcademyContent.description: Interpret bar graphs to answer questions about a context.

khanAcademyContent.name: Read picture graphs (multi-step problems)
khanAcademyContent.description: Interpret picture graphs to answer questions about a context.

khanAcademyContent.name: Read picture graphs
khanAcademyContent.description: Use picture graphs to solve word problems.

data.description: Generate measurement data by measuring lengths using rulers marked with halves and fourths of an inch. Show the data by making a line plot, where the horizontal scale is marked off in appropriate units— whole numbers, halves, or quarters.

khanAcademyContent.name: Read line plots (data with fractions)
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice reading and interpreting data that is graphed on line plots. The data graphed includes fractions.

khanAcademyContent.name: Graph data on line plots
khanAcademyContent.description: Record measurements on line plots (also called dot plots).

children.name: Geometric Measurement: Understand Concepts Of Area And Relate Area To Multiplication And To Addition.

data.description: A square with side length 1 unit, called “a unit square,” is said to have “one square unit” of area, and can be used to measure area.
A plane figure which can be covered without gaps or overlaps by n unit squares is said to have an area of n square units.
Recognize area as an attribute of plane figures and understand concepts of area measurement.

khanAcademyContent.name: Find area by counting unit squares
khanAcademyContent.description: Find the area of shapes by counting the unit squares inside them.

khanAcademyContent.name: Understanding area
khanAcademyContent.description: Compare the amount of unit squares that cover figures.

data.description: Measure areas by counting unit squares (square cm, square m, square in, square ft, and improvised units).

khanAcademyContent.name: Create rectangles with a given area
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice finding the area of rectangles by counting unit square. Create rectangles with a given area by covering unit squares.

khanAcademyContent.name: Find area by counting unit squares
khanAcademyContent.description: Find the area of shapes by counting the unit squares inside them.

khanAcademyContent.name: Find area with partial unit squares
khanAcademyContent.description: Count unit squares and partial unit squares to find the area of shapes.

data.description: Find the area of a rectangle with whole-number side lengths by tiling it, and show that the area is the same as would be found by multiplying the side lengths.

Multiply side lengths to find areas of rectangles with whole- number side lengths in the context of solving real world and mathematical problems, and represent whole-number products as rectangular areas in mathematical reasoning.

Use tiling to show in a concrete case that the area of a rectangle with whole-number side lengths a and b + c is the sum of a × b and a × c. Use area models to represent the distributive property in mathematical reasoning.

Recognize area as additive. Find areas of rectilinear figures by decomposing them into non-overlapping rectangles and adding the areas of the non-overlapping parts, applying this technique to solve real world problems.
Relate area to the operations of multiplication and addition.

khanAcademyContent.name: Compare areas by multiplying
khanAcademyContent.description: Compare the areas of rectangles represented in images or contexts.

khanAcademyContent.name: Find a missing side length when given area
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice finding a missing side length on a rectangle when given the other side length and the area.

khanAcademyContent.name: Measure to find area
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice measuring the side-lengths of a rectangle to find its area.

khanAcademyContent.name: Area of rectangles
khanAcademyContent.description: Find area of rectangles and squares by multiplying side lengths.

khanAcademyContent.name: Area and the distributive property
khanAcademyContent.description: Use area models to represent the distributive property in finding area of rectangles.

khanAcademyContent.name: Decompose figures to find area 1
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice decomposing figures into rectangles to find area. Some figures are on grids.

khanAcademyContent.name: Decompose figures to find area 2
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice decomposing irregular shapes to find their area.

khanAcademyContent.name: Transition from unit squares to area formula
khanAcademyContent.description: Find area of rectangles by multiplying side-lengths.

children.name: Geometric Measurement: Recognize Perimeter As An Attribute Of Plane Figures And Distinguish Between Linear And Area Measures.

data.description: Solve real world and mathematical problems involving perimeters of polygons, including finding the perimeter given the side lengths, finding an unknown side length, and exhibiting rectangles with the same perimeter and different areas or with the same area and different perimeters.

khanAcademyContent.name: Find a missing side length when given perimeter
khanAcademyContent.description: Find a missing side length for a figure when given the perimeter.

khanAcademyContent.name: Find perimeter by counting unit squares
khanAcademyContent.description: Calculate the perimeter of a rectangle from its side lengths.

khanAcademyContent.name: Find perimeter when given side lengths
khanAcademyContent.description: Find perimeter of figures when given an image or context.

khanAcademyContent.name: Perimeter word problems
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice solving real world word problems involving perimeter.

khanAcademyContent.name: Compare area and perimeter
khanAcademyContent.description: Compare the areas and perimeters of rectangles when given a context or picture.

khanAcademyContent.name: Measure to find perimeter
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice measuring side lengths to find perimeter.

children.name: Number And Operations In Base Ten

Use Place Value Understanding And Properties Of Operations To Perform Multi-Digit Arithmetic.*

 

*A range of algorithms may be used.

data.description:
Use place value understanding to round whole numbers to the nearest 10 or 100.

*A range of algorithms may be used.

khanAcademyContent.name: Round to nearest 10 or 100 on the number line
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice rounding to the nearest ten and rounding to the nearest hundred on the number line.

khanAcademyContent.name: Round to nearest 10 or 100
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice rounding to the nearest ten and rounding to the nearest hundred.

khanAcademyContent.name: Rounding challenge
khanAcademyContent.description: Give your brain a workout with these challenge problems on rounding.

data.description:
Fluently add and subtract within 1000 using strategies and algorithms based on place value, properties of operations, and/or the relationship between addition and subtraction.

*A range of algorithms may be used.

khanAcademyContent.name: Subtract within 1000
khanAcademyContent.description: Subtract with 2 numbers less than 1000.

khanAcademyContent.name: Estimate to add and subtract multi-digit whole numbers
khanAcademyContent.description: Use estimation to find a reasonable solution to multi-digit addition and subtraction problems. Numbers are less than or equal to 1000.

khanAcademyContent.name: Add within 1000
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice adding three-digit numbers. All sums are 1000 or less.

khanAcademyContent.name: Add using groups of 10 and 100
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice making groups of 10 and 100 while adding 3-digit numbers.

khanAcademyContent.name: Break apart 3-digit addition problems
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice breaking apart big addition problems using place value. For example, 234+567 is the same as 200+500+30+60+4+7.

data.description:
Multiply one-digit whole numbers by multiples of 10 in the range 10–90 (e.g., 9 × 80, 5 × 60) using strategies based on place value and properties of operations.

*A range of algorithms may be used.

khanAcademyContent.name: Multiply by tens word problems
khanAcademyContent.description: Solve word problems with multiples of ten.  Decompose multiples of ten to multiply.

khanAcademyContent.name: Multiply by tens
khanAcademyContent.description: Multiply a 1-digit number by a multiple of 10.

children.name: Number And Operations-Fractions*
Develop Understanding Of Fractions As Numbers.

data.description:
Understand a fraction 1/b as the quantity formed by 1 part when a whole is partitioned into b equal parts; understand a fraction a/b as the quantity formed by a parts of size 1/b.

*Grade 3 expectations in this domain are limited to fractions with denominators 2, 3, 4, 6, and 8.

khanAcademyContent.name: Cut shapes into equal parts
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice telling if a shape has been divided into equal parts.

khanAcademyContent.name: Recognize fractions
khanAcademyContent.description: Identify the fraction of a whole that is shaded.  Fractions are less than 1.

khanAcademyContent.name: Identify numerators and denominators
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice identifying numerators and denominators in fractions.

khanAcademyContent.name: Recognize fractions greater than 1
khanAcademyContent.description: Identify the fraction of a whole that is shaded.  Fractions are greater than or equal to one.

khanAcademyContent.name: Identify unit fractions
khanAcademyContent.description: Identify unit fractions when given a visual or a context.

data.description: Represent a fraction 1/b on a number line diagram by defining the interval from 0 to 1 as the whole and partitioning it into b equal parts. Recognize that each part has size 1/b and that the endpoint of the part based at 0 locates the number 1/b on the number line.

Represent a fraction a/b on a number line diagram by marking off a lengths 1/b from 0. Recognize that the resulting interval has size a/b and that its endpoint locates the number a/b on the number line.

Understand a fraction as a number on the number line; represent fractions on a number line diagram.

*Grade 3 expectations in this domain are limited to fractions with denominators 2, 3, 4, 6, and 8.

khanAcademyContent.name: Relate fractions to 1
khanAcademyContent.description: Determine whether fractions are greater than, less than, or equal to one.

khanAcademyContent.name: Fractions on the number line
khanAcademyContent.description: Plot and spot fractions on the number line.

khanAcademyContent.name: Find 1 on the number line
khanAcademyContent.description: Locate 1 on a number line labeled with 0 and a unit fraction.

khanAcademyContent.name: Unit fractions on the number line
khanAcademyContent.description: Use unit fractions to think about the location of other fractions on the number line.

data.description: Understand two fractions as equivalent (equal) if they are the same size, or the same point on a number line.
Recognize and generate simple equivalent fractions, e.g., 1/2 = 2/4, 4/6 = 2/3). Explain why the fractions are equivalent, e.g., by using a visual fraction model.

Express whole numbers as fractions, and recognize fractions that are equivalent to whole numbers. Examples: Express 3 in the form 3 = 3/1; recognize that 6/1 = 6; locate 4/4 and 1 at the same point of a number line diagram.

Compare two fractions with the same numerator or the same denominator by reasoning about their size. Recognize that comparisons are valid only when the two fractions refer to the same whole. Record the results of comparisons with the symbols >, =, or <, and justify the conclusions, e.g., by using a visual fraction model.

Explain equivalence of fractions in special cases, and compare fractions by reasoning about their size.

*Grade 3 expectations in this domain are limited to fractions with denominators 2, 3, 4, 6, and 8.

khanAcademyContent.name: Compare fractions of different wholes
khanAcademyContent.description: Compare two fractions based on the whole that each one refers to.

khanAcademyContent.name: Compare fractions with the same numerator or denominator
khanAcademyContent.description: Compare two fractions that have either the same numerator or denominator.

khanAcademyContent.name: Equivalent fractions on the number line
khanAcademyContent.description: Graph and identify equivalent fractions on a number line.

khanAcademyContent.name: Compare fractions with the same numerator
khanAcademyContent.description: Compare two fractions that have the same numerator using greater and less than symbols.

khanAcademyContent.name: Relate fractions to 1
khanAcademyContent.description: Determine whether fractions are greater than, less than, or equal to one.

khanAcademyContent.name: Compare fractions with the same denominator
khanAcademyContent.description: Compare two fractions that have the same denominator using greater and less than symbols.

khanAcademyContent.name: Write fractions as whole numbers
khanAcademyContent.description: Represent fractions as whole numbers and whole numbers as fractions.

khanAcademyContent.name: Equivalent fraction models
khanAcademyContent.description: Identify and create equivalent fractions using visual models.

khanAcademyContent.name: Visually compare fractions 1
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice comparing fractions with the help of visuals aides.

children.name: Operations And Algebraic Thinking
Represent And Solve Problems Involving Multiplication And Division.

data.description: Interpret products of whole numbers, e.g., interpret 5 × 7 as the total number of objects in 5 groups of 7 objects each. For example, describe a context in which a total number of objects can be expressed as 5 × 7.

khanAcademyContent.name: Meaning of multiplication
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice representing multiplication as equal groups, repeated addition, or arrays.

khanAcademyContent.name: Multiply with arrays
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice multiplying 1-digit numbers using arrays.

data.description: Interpret whole-number quotients of whole numbers, e.g., interpret 56 ÷ 8 as the number of objects in each share when 56 objects are partitioned equally into 8 shares, or as a number of shares when 56 objects are partitioned into equal shares of 8 objects each. For example, describe a context in which a number of shares or a number of groups can be expressed as 56 ÷ 8.

khanAcademyContent.name: Divide with visuals
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice basic division using various visuals, such as arrays.

khanAcademyContent.name: Meaning of division
khanAcademyContent.description: Use visual models to understand division.

data.description:
Use multiplication and division within 100 to solve word problems in situations involving equal groups, arrays, and measurement quantities, e.g., by using drawings and equations with a symbol for the unknown number to represent the problem.*

*See Glossary, Table 2

khanAcademyContent.name: Multiplication and division word problems (within 100)
khanAcademyContent.description: Solve word problems involving multiplication and division. Solutions will be less than or equal to 100.

khanAcademyContent.name: Relate division to multiplication word problems
khanAcademyContent.description: Find both the multiplication and division equation that can be used to solve a word problem.

data.description: Determine the unknown whole number in a multiplication or division equation relating three whole numbers. For example, determine the unknown number that makes the equation true in each of the equations 8 × ? = 48, 5 = ? ÷ 3, 6 × 6 = ?.

khanAcademyContent.name: Letters and symbols in multiplication and division equations
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice solving for unknown letters and symbols in equations.

khanAcademyContent.name: Find missing divisors and dividends (1-digit division)
khanAcademyContent.description: Find missing divisors and dividends in 1-digit division problems.  Quotients are less than or equal to 10.

khanAcademyContent.name: Find missing factors (1-digit multiplication)
khanAcademyContent.description: Find missing factors in 1-digit multiplication problems. Products are less than or equal to 100.

khanAcademyContent.name: Basic multiplication
khanAcademyContent.description: Multiply two 1-digit numbers. Some problems include multiplying by 10.

children.name: Understand Properties Of Multiplication And The Relationship Between Multiplication And Division.

data.description:
Apply properties of operations as strategies to multiply and divide.* Examples: If 6 × 4 = 24 is known, then 4 × 6 = 24 is also known. (Commutative property of multiplication.) 3 × 5 × 2 can be found by 3 × 5 = 15, then 15 × 2 = 30, or by 5 × 2 = 10, then 3 × 10 = 30. (Associative property of multiplication.) Knowing that 8 × 5 = 40 and 8 × 2 = 16, one can find 8 × 7 as 8 × (5 + 2) = (8 × 5) + (8 × 2) = 40 + 16 = 56. (Distributive property.)

*Students need not use formal terms for these properties.

khanAcademyContent.name: Commutative property of multiplication
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice changing the order of factors in a multiplication problem and see how it affects the product.

khanAcademyContent.name: Associative property of multiplication
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice changing the grouping of factors in multiplication problems and see how it affects the product.

khanAcademyContent.name: Distributive property of multiplication
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice decomposing the factors in multiplication problems and see how it affects the product.

data.description: Understand division as an unknown-factor problem. For example, find 32 ÷ 8 by finding the number that makes 32 when multiplied by 8.

khanAcademyContent.name: Relate division to multiplication word problems
khanAcademyContent.description: Find both the multiplication and division equation that can be used to solve a word problem.

khanAcademyContent.name: Relate division to multiplication
khanAcademyContent.description: See the relationship between multiplication and division problems.

data.description: Fluently multiply and divide within 100, using strategies such as the relationship between multiplication and division (e.g., knowing that 8 × 5 = 40, one knows 40 ÷ 5 = 8) or properties of operations. By the end of Grade 3, know from memory all products of two one-digit numbers.

khanAcademyContent.description: Practice skip counting to find a number on a number line with only two tick marks labeled.

khanAcademyContent.description: Find missing divisors and dividends in 1-digit division problems.  Quotients are less than or equal to 10.

khanAcademyContent.description: Multiply two 1-digit numbers. Some problems include multiplying by 10.

khanAcademyContent.description: Divide by 5.  Quotients are less than or equal to 10.

khanAcademyContent.description: Practice transitioning from repeated addition to multiplication. Understand that '5+5+5' is the same as '3 fives' or '3x5'.

khanAcademyContent.description: Divide by 8.  Quotients are less than or equal to 10.

children.name: Solve Problems Involving The Four Operations, And Identify And Explain Patterns In Arithmetic.

data.description:
Solve two-step word problems using the four operations. Represent these problems using equations with a letter standing for the unknown quantity. Assess the reasonableness of answers using mental computation and estimation strategies including rounding.*

*This standard is limited to problems posed with whole numbers and having wholenumber answers; students should know how to perform operations in the conventional order when there are no parentheses to specify a particular order (Order of Operations).

khanAcademyContent.name: Represent 2-step word problems with equations
khanAcademyContent.description: Represent two-step word problems using equations with a letter standing for the unknown quantity. Equations include addition, subtraction, multiplication, and division.

khanAcademyContent.name: 2-step word problems
khanAcademyContent.description: Solve two-step word problems with addition, subtraction, multiplication, and division.  Some questions include estimation.

khanAcademyContent.description: Use estimation to solve two-step word problems involving addition, subtraction, multiplication, and division.

data.description: Identify arithmetic patterns (including patterns in the addition table or multiplication table), and explain them using properties of operations. For example, observe that 4 times a number is always even, and explain why 4 times a number can be decomposed into two equal addends.

khanAcademyContent.name: Math patterns 1
khanAcademyContent.description: Identify arithmetic patterns (including ones in the addition or multiplication tables), and explain them using properties of operations.

Draw And Identify Lines And Angles, And Classify Shapes By Properties Of Their Lines And Angles.

khanAcademyContent.description: Determine if angles in shapes and pictures are acute, right, or obtuse.

khanAcademyContent.description: Practice drawing lines of symmetry and creating symmetrical figures.

khanAcademyContent.name: Identify symmetrical figures
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice identifying symmetrical shapes.

children.name: Measurement And Data
Solve Problems Involving Measurement And Conversion Of Measurements From A Larger Unit To A Smaller Unit.

data.description: Know relative sizes of measurement units within one system of units including km, m, cm; kg, g; lb, oz.; l, ml; hr, min, sec. Within a single system of measurement, express measurements in a larger unit in terms of a smaller unit. Record measurement equivalents in a two- column table. For example, know that 1 ft is 12 times as long as 1 in. Express the length of a 4 ft snake as 48 in. Generate a conversion table for feet and inches listing the number pairs (1, 12), (2, 24), (3, 36), ...

khanAcademyContent.name: Convert to smaller units (g and kg)
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice converting a metric measure of mass to a smaller unit.

khanAcademyContent.name: Convert to smaller units (mL and L)
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice converting a metric measure of volume to a smaller unit.

khanAcademyContent.name: Estimating length (in, ft, yd, and mi)
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice estimating the length of real life objects using US customary units.

khanAcademyContent.name: Convert to smaller units (mm, cm, m, & km)
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice converting a metric measure of length to a smaller unit.

khanAcademyContent.name: Estimating mass (ounces and pounds)
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice estimating the mass of real life objects using US customary units.

khanAcademyContent.name: Estimate volume (milliliters and liters)
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice estimating the volume of real life objects using milliliters and liters.

khanAcademyContent.name: Estimating volume (cups, pints, quarts, and gallons)
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice estimating the volume of real life objects using US customary units.

khanAcademyContent.name: Convert to smaller units (c, pt, qt, & gal)
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice converting a US customary measure of volume to a smaller unit.

khanAcademyContent.name: Convert to smaller units (oz and lb)
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice converting a US customary measure of mass to a smaller unit.

khanAcademyContent.name: Estimating length (mm, cm, m, km)
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice estimating the length of real life objects using metric units.

khanAcademyContent.name: Convert to smaller units (sec, min, & hr)
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice converting a measure of time to a smaller unit.

khanAcademyContent.name: Estimate mass (grams and kilograms)
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice estimating the mass of real life objects using grams and kilograms.

khanAcademyContent.name: Convert to smaller units (in, ft, yd, & mi)
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice converting a US customary measure of length to a smaller unit.

khanAcademyContent.name: Estimating time (seconds, minutes, and hours)
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice estimating the length of an event using seconds, minutes, and hours.

data.description: Use the four operations to solve word problems involving distances, intervals of time, liquid volumes, masses of objects, and money, including problems involving simple fractions or decimals, and problems that require expressing measurements given in a larger unit in terms of a smaller unit. Represent measurement quantities using diagrams such as number line diagrams that feature a measurement scale.

khanAcademyContent.name: US customary conversion word problems
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice US customary length, volume, and mass problems that require expressing measurements given in a larger unit in terms of a smaller unit.

khanAcademyContent.name: Telling time word problems
khanAcademyContent.description: Solve a word problem to find the duration of an event. Both analog or digital clocks are included. Time in the word problems crosses over the hour.

khanAcademyContent.name: Convert money word problems
khanAcademyContent.description: Solve word problems that involve converting between U.S. dollars and cents and converting U.S. dollars to other units of money, like pesos.

khanAcademyContent.name: Metric conversions word problems
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice metric length, volume, and mass problems that require expressing measurements given in a larger unit in terms of a smaller unit.

khanAcademyContent.name: Time conversion word problems
khanAcademyContent.description: Solve word problems to find what time an event occurred or how long an event lasted.

khanAcademyContent.name: Time differences
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice finding the difference between times given on two analog clocks. Time differences cross over the hour.

data.description: Apply the area and perimeter formulas for rectangles in real world and mathematical problems. For example, find the width of a rectangular room given the area of the flooring and the length, by viewing the area formula as a multiplication equation with an unknown factor.

khanAcademyContent.name: Area & perimeter of rectangles word problems
khanAcademyContent.description: Find the missing side length of a rectangle when given its perimeter or area.  Compare perimeters and areas of rectangles.

khanAcademyContent.name: Area of squares and rectangles
khanAcademyContent.description: Find the area of rectangles and squares when given side lengths.  Find the side length of a square when given the area.

children.name: Represent And Interpret Data.

data.description: Make a line plot to display a data set of measurements in fractions of a unit (1/2, 1/4, 1/8). Solve problems involving addition and subtraction of fractions by using information presented in line plots. For example, from a line plot find and interpret the difference in length between the longest and shortest specimens in an insect collection.

khanAcademyContent.name: Interpret dot plots with fractions 1
khanAcademyContent.description: Create and interpret dot plots using data with fractions.  Fraction operations include addition and subtraction.

children.name: Geometric Measurement: Understand Concepts Of Angle And Measure Angles.

data.description: An angle is measured with reference to a circle with its center at the common endpoint of the rays, by considering the fraction of the circular arc between the points where the two rays intersect the circle. An angle that turns through 1/360 of a circle is called a “one-degree angle,” and can be used to measure angles.
An angle that turns through n one-degree angles is said to have an angle measure of n degrees.
Recognize angles as geometric shapes that are formed wherever two rays share a common endpoint, and understand concepts of angle measurement:

khanAcademyContent.name: Angles in circles
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice measuring angles using a circle protractor, solve problems about angles as part of a circle.

khanAcademyContent.name: Benchmark angles
khanAcademyContent.description: Estimate the size of angles when given a picture or a situation.

khanAcademyContent.name: Name angles
khanAcademyContent.description: Name angles by their vertex, endpoints, or labels.

khanAcademyContent.name: Angle basics
khanAcademyContent.description: Determine which angle has a greater measure by looking at the size of the opening between the angle's rays.

data.description: Measure angles in whole-number degrees using a protractor. Sketch angles of specified measure.

khanAcademyContent.name: Draw angles
khanAcademyContent.description: Use a protractor to construct angles.

khanAcademyContent.name: Angles in circles
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice measuring angles using a circle protractor, solve problems about angles as part of a circle.

khanAcademyContent.name: Measure angles
khanAcademyContent.description: Measure angles using a protractor.

data.description: Recognize angle measure as additive. When an angle is decomposed into non-overlapping parts, the angle measure of the whole is the sum of the angle measures of the parts. Solve addition and subtraction problems to find unknown angles on a diagram in real world and mathematical problems, e.g., by using an equation with a symbol for the unknown angle measure.

khanAcademyContent.name: Decompose angles
khanAcademyContent.description: Find an angle's measure when given the measures of its parts.

children.name: Number And Operations In Base Ten*
Generalize Place Value Understanding For Multi-Digit Whole Numbers.

data.description:
Recognize that in a multi-digit whole number, a digit in one place represents ten times what it represents in the place to its right. For example, recognize that 700 ÷ 70 = 10 by applying concepts of place value and division.

*Grade 4 expectations in this domain are limited to whole numbers less than or equal to 1,000,000.

khanAcademyContent.name: Place value when multiplying and dividing by 10
khanAcademyContent.description: Recognize that in a multi-digit whole number, a digit in one place represents ten times what it represents in the place to its right.

khanAcademyContent.name: Place value blocks
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice using place value blocks.

khanAcademyContent.name: Divide whole numbers by 10
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice dividing whole numbers by 10.

khanAcademyContent.name: Multiply whole numbers by 10
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice multiplying whole numbers by 10.

khanAcademyContent.name: Multiply and divide by 10
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice multiplying and dividing whole numbers by ten.

khanAcademyContent.name: Creating largest or smallest number
khanAcademyContent.description: Sal arranges digits to make the largest or smallest possible number.

data.description:
Read and write multi-digit whole numbers using base-ten numerals, number names, and expanded form. Compare two multi-digit numbers based on meanings of the digits in each place, using >, =, and < symbols to record the results of comparisons.

*Grade 4 expectations in this domain are limited to whole numbers less than or equal to 1,000,000.

khanAcademyContent.name: Intro to place value
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice thinking about the value of each digit in a number.

khanAcademyContent.name: Compare multi-digit numbers word problems
khanAcademyContent.description: Solve word problems by comparing whole numbers.

khanAcademyContent.name: Write whole numbers in expanded form
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice reading and writing numbers written in expanded form. Example: The expanded form of 376 is 300 + 70 + 6.

khanAcademyContent.name: Compare numbers: place value challenge
khanAcademyContent.description: Compare multi-digit numbers that challenge your place value understanding

khanAcademyContent.name: Whole number place value challenge
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice problems to challenge your understanding of whole number place value

khanAcademyContent.name: Compare multi-digit numbers
khanAcademyContent.description: Use your place value skills to practice comparing whole numbers.

khanAcademyContent.name: Write numbers in written form
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice working with whole numbers in written form. For example, "one thousand four hundred three" is the written form of 1403.

data.description:
Use place value understanding to round multi-digit whole numbers to any place.

*Grade 4 expectations in this domain are limited to whole numbers less than or equal to 1,000,000.

khanAcademyContent.name: Round whole numbers word problems
khanAcademyContent.description: Solve word problems by rounding whole numbers.

khanAcademyContent.name: Round whole numbers challenge
khanAcademyContent.description: More challenging practice problems where you round whole numbers to the nearest hundred or thousand

khanAcademyContent.name: Round whole numbers
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice rounding whole numbers to the nearest hundred or thousand.

children.name: Use Place Value Understanding And Properties Of Operations To Perform Multi-Digit Arithmetic.

data.description:
Fluently add and subtract multi-digit whole numbers using the standard algorithm.

*Grade 4 expectations in this domain are limited to whole numbers less than or equal to 1,000,000.

khanAcademyContent.name: Multi-digit addition
khanAcademyContent.description: Add whole numbers with sums less than 1,000,000.

khanAcademyContent.name: Multi-digit subtraction
khanAcademyContent.description: Subtract whole numbers that are less than or equal to 1,000,000.

data.description:
Multiply a whole number of up to four digits by a one-digit whole number, and multiply two two-digit numbers, using strategies based on place value and the properties of operations. Illustrate and explain the calculation by using equations, rectangular arrays, and/or area models.

*Grade 4 expectations in this domain are limited to whole numbers less than or equal to 1,000,000.

khanAcademyContent.name: Multiply with regrouping
khanAcademyContent.description: Multiply 3- or 4-digit numbers by 1-digit numbers. Regrouping (carrying) needed.

khanAcademyContent.name: Multiply 1-digit numbers by 10, 100, and 1000
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice multiplication problems like 5x100=500.

khanAcademyContent.name: Multiplying 10s
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice multiplying 2-digit multiples of 10, such as 50x70=3500.

khanAcademyContent.name: Multiply 2-digit numbers with area models
khanAcademyContent.description: Use an area model to decompose factors and multiply.

khanAcademyContent.name: Multiply 2-digit numbers
khanAcademyContent.description: Multiply 2-digit numbers by 2-digit numbers. Regrouping (carrying) needed.

khanAcademyContent.name: Multiply using place value
khanAcademyContent.description: Multiply a 1-digit number by a multi-digit number by decomposing the multi-digit number.

khanAcademyContent.name: Multiply 2-, 3-, and 4-digits by 1-digit with area models
khanAcademyContent.description: Use an area model to decompose the larger factor and multiply.

khanAcademyContent.name: Multiply 1-digit numbers by a multiple of 10, 100, and 1000
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice multiplication problems like 5x500=2500.

khanAcademyContent.name: Multiply without regrouping
khanAcademyContent.description: Multiply 2- or 3-digit numbers by 1-digit numbers. No regrouping or carrying.

data.description:
Find whole-number quotients and remainders with up to four-digit dividends and one-digit divisors, using strategies based on place value, the properties of operations, and/or the relationship between multiplication and division. Illustrate and explain the calculation by using equations, rectangular arrays, and/or area models.

*Grade 4 expectations in this domain are limited to whole numbers less than or equal to 1,000,000.

khanAcademyContent.name: Divide with remainders (basic)
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice finding remainders in small division problems, like 24÷5.

khanAcademyContent.name: Divide by 1-digit numbers (visual models)
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice breaking up big division problems into smaller, simpler problems.

khanAcademyContent.name: Zeros in the dividend (no remainders)
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice solving division problems with 0s in the dividend (for example, 204÷4).

khanAcademyContent.name: Zeros in the quotient (no remainders)
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice solving division problems with 0s in the solution, or quotient.

khanAcademyContent.name: Divide with remainders
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice finding remainders in division problems, like 247÷5.

khanAcademyContent.name: Intro to remainders
khanAcademyContent.description: Use arrays, area models, and practice problems to understand remainders.

khanAcademyContent.name: Quotients that are multiples of 10
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice division problems that work out to multiples of ten. Example: 1200 ÷ 30 = 40.

khanAcademyContent.name: Divide using place value
khanAcademyContent.description: Decompose 3- and 4-digit dividends to divide them by a 1-digit divisor.

khanAcademyContent.name: Cancel zeros when dividing
khanAcademyContent.description: Learn to cancel zeros when dividing numbers like 3000 and 50.

khanAcademyContent.name: Divide by 1-digit numbers (no remainders)
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice dividing 2-, 3-, and 4-digit numbers by a 1-digit number.

children.name: Number And Operations-Fractions*
Extend Understanding Of Fraction Equivalence And Ordering.

data.description:
Explain why a fraction a/b is equivalent to a fraction (n × a)/(n × b) by using visual fraction models, with attention to how the number and size of the parts differ even though the two fractions themselves are the same size. Use this principle to recognize and generate equivalent fractions.

*Grade 4 expectations in this domain are limited to fractions with denominators 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 8, 10, 12, and 100.

khanAcademyContent.name: Equivalent fractions
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice making equivalent fractions by multiplying the numerator and denominator by the same number.

khanAcademyContent.name: Equivalent fractions (fraction models)
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice finding equivalent fractions. These problems show you pictures of fractions to help you out.

data.description:
Compare two fractions with different numerators and different denominators, e.g., by creating common denominators or numerators, or by comparing to a benchmark fraction such as 1/2. Recognize that comparisons are valid only when the two fractions refer to the same whole. Record the results of comparisons with symbols >, =, or <, and justify the conclusions, e.g., by using a visual fraction model.

*Grade 4 expectations in this domain are limited to fractions with denominators 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 8, 10, 12, and 100.

khanAcademyContent.name: Compare fractions and mixed numbers
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice comparing fractions and mixed numbers that have unlike denominators.

khanAcademyContent.name: Common denominators
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice rewriting fractions to have the same denominator.

khanAcademyContent.name: Visually compare fractions with unlike denominators
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice comparing fractions by looking at pictures. Fractions in these problems do not have common denominators.

khanAcademyContent.name: Order fractions
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice ordering 3 fractions from least to greatest.

khanAcademyContent.name: Equivalent fractions and different wholes
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice using the same whole to find equivalent fractions.

khanAcademyContent.name: Compare fractions with different numerators and denominators
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice comparing two fractions with different denominators with greater and less than symbols.

children.name: Build Fractions From Unit Fractions By Applying And Extending Previous Understandings Of Operations On Whole Numbers.

data.description: Understand addition and subtraction of fractions as joining and separating parts referring to the same whole.
