Decompose a fraction into a sum of fractions with the same denominator in more than one way, recording each decomposition by an equation. Justify decompositions, e.g., by using a visual fraction model. Examples: 3/8 = 1/8 + 1/8 + 1/8 ; 3/8 = 1/8 + 2/8 ; 2 1/8 = 1 + 1 + 1/8 = 8/8 + 8/8 + 1/8.

Add and subtract mixed numbers with like denominators, e.g., by replacing each mixed number with an equivalent fraction, and/or by using properties of operations and the relationship between addition and subtraction.

Solve word problems involving addition and subtraction of fractions referring to the same whole and having like denominators, e.g., by using visual fraction models and equations to represent the problem.

Understand a fraction a/b with a > 1 as a sum of fractions 1/b.

*Grade 4 expectations in this domain are limited to fractions with denominators 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 8, 10, 12, and 100.

khanAcademyContent.name: Add and subtract mixed numbers (with regrouping)
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice adding and subtracting mixed numbers with common (like) denominators. Items require regrouping (borrowing).

khanAcademyContent.name: Add and subtract mixed numbers word problems (like denominators)
khanAcademyContent.description: Solve addition and subtraction word problems involving fractions and mixed numbers. Fractions and mixed numbers have common denominators.

khanAcademyContent.name: Add and subtract fractions word problems (same denominator)
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice solving word problems by adding and subtracting fractions. The fractions used in these problems have like (common) denominators.

khanAcademyContent.name: Add and subtract mixed numbers (no regrouping)
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice adding and subtracting mixed numbers with common (like) denominators.

khanAcademyContent.name: Add fractions with common denominators
khanAcademyContent.description: Add two fractions with the like denominators.

khanAcademyContent.name: Decompose fractions
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice decomposing fractions (breaking fractions into parts that can be added together).

khanAcademyContent.name: Subtract fractions with common denominators
khanAcademyContent.description: Solve a subtraction problem with two fractions with like denominators.

khanAcademyContent.name: Rewrite mixed numbers and improper fractions
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice writing a fraction as a mixed number and vice versa.

data.description: Understand a fraction a/b as a multiple of 1/b. For example, use a visual fraction model to represent 5/4 as the product 5 × (1/4), recording the conclusion by the equation 5/4 = 5 × (1/4).

Understand a multiple of a/b as a multiple of 1/b, and use this understanding to multiply a fraction by a whole number. For example, use a visual fraction model to express 3 × (2/5) as 6 × (1/5), recognizing this product as 6/5. (In general, n × (a/b) = (n × a)/b.)

Solve word problems involving multiplication of a fraction by a whole number, e.g., by using visual fraction models and equations to represent the problem. For example, if each person at a party will eat 3/8 of a pound of roast beef, and there will be 5 people at the party, how many pounds of roast beef will be needed? Between what two whole numbers does your answer lie?

Apply and extend previous understandings of multiplication to multiply a fraction by a whole number.

*Grade 4 expectations in this domain are limited to fractions with denominators 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 8, 10, 12, and 100.

khanAcademyContent.name: Multiply unit fractions and whole numbers
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice multiplying unit fractions (fractions with a 1 in the numerator) and whole numbers.

khanAcademyContent.name: Interpret multiplying fraction and whole number word problems
khanAcademyContent.description: Solve word problems involving multiplication of a fraction by a whole number.  Then interpret the solution by, for example, determining between which two whole numbers the solution falls.

khanAcademyContent.name: Multiply fractions and whole numbers
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice multiplying a whole number times a fraction.

khanAcademyContent.name: Equivalent unit fraction and whole number multiplication expressions
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice seeing how one whole-number-times-fraction problem is the same as another.  Find equivalent multiplication expressions.

khanAcademyContent.name: Multiply fractions and whole numbers intuition
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice matching fraction diagrams and number lines to multiplication expressions.

khanAcademyContent.name: Multiply fractions and whole numbers word problems
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice solving multiplication word problems that include whole numbers and fractions.

children.name: Understand Decimal Notation For Fractions, And Compare Decimal Fractions.

data.description:
Express a fraction with denominator 10 as an equivalent fraction with denominator 100, and use this technique to add two fractions with respective denominators 10 and 100.* For example, express 3/10 as 30/100, and add 3/10 + 4/100 = 34/100.

*Students who can generate equivalent fractions can develop strategies for adding fractions with unlike denominators in general. But addition and subtraction with unlike denominators in general is not a requirement at this grade.

**Grade 4 expectations in this domain are limited to fractions with denominators 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 8, 10, 12, and 100.

khanAcademyContent.name: Equivalent fractions (denominators 10 & 100)
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice writing equivalent fractions with denominators of 10 and 100.

khanAcademyContent.name: Decompose fractions with denominators of 100
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice breaking apart (decomposing) some number of hundredths into tenths and hundredths.

khanAcademyContent.name: Add fractions (denominators 10 & 100)
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice adding fractions that have denominators of 10 and 100.

khanAcademyContent.name: Equivalent fractions with fraction models (denominators 10 & 100)
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice writing equivalent fractions with denominators of 10 and 100. These problems give you pictures to help you find the answer.

khanAcademyContent.name: Equivalent expressions with common denominators (denominators 10 & 100)
khanAcademyContent.description: Rewrite a fraction addition problem so the fractions have common denominators.  All items have denominators of either 10 or 100.

data.description:
Use decimal notation for fractions with denominators 10 or 100. For example, rewrite 0.62 as 62/100; describe a length as 0.62 meters; locate 0.62 on a number line diagram.

*Grade 4 expectations in this domain are limited to fractions with denominators 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 8, 10, 12, and 100.

khanAcademyContent.name: Rewrite fractions as decimals (denominators of 10 & 100)
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice rewriting fractions as decimals. Fractions in these problems have denominators of 10 and 100.

khanAcademyContent.name: Decimals on the number line: hundredths
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice finding decimal numbers on the number line. Decimals are limited to hundredths.

khanAcademyContent.name: Decimals on the number line: hundredths 0-0.1
khanAcademyContent.description: Graph hundredths between 0 and 0.1 on a number line.

khanAcademyContent.name: Write number as a fraction and decimal
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice these problems to see how decimals and fractions can represent the same number.

khanAcademyContent.name: Decimals in words
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice writing decimal numbers in word form and number form.

khanAcademyContent.name: Write decimal numbers shown in grids
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice writing decimal numbers shown in grid diagrams.

khanAcademyContent.name: Place value for decimals greater than 1
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice your decimal place value understanding by using tenths and hundredths to describe decimal numbers greater than one.

khanAcademyContent.name: Rewrite decimals as fractions
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice rewriting decimals as fractions. These problems use decimals with tenths and hundredths.

khanAcademyContent.name: Decimals on the number line: tenths 0-1
khanAcademyContent.description: Graph tenths between 0 and 1 on the number line.

khanAcademyContent.name: Decimals on the number line: tenths
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice finding decimal numbers on the number line. Decimals are limited to tenths in these problems.

data.description:
Compare two decimals to hundredths by reasoning about their size. Recognize that comparisons are valid only when the two decimals refer to the same whole. Record the results of comparisons with the symbols >, =, or <, and justify the conclusions, e.g., by using a visual model.

*Grade 4 expectations in this domain are limited to fractions with denominators 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 8, 10, 12, and 100.

khanAcademyContent.name: Compare decimals and fractions
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice comparing decimals and fractions. Decimals and fractions in these problems are limited to tenths and hundredths for easier comparison.

khanAcademyContent.name: Compare decimals visually
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice comparing decimals with the help of visual aids.

khanAcademyContent.name: Compare decimals (tenths and hundredths)
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice comparing decimals. Decimals in these problems are limited to tenths and hundredths.

children.name: Operations And Algebraic Thinking
Use The Four Operations With Whole Numbers To Solve Problems.

data.description: Interpret a multiplication equation as a comparison, e.g., interpret 35 = 5 × 7 as a statement that 35 is 5 times as many as 7 and 7 times as many as 5. Represent verbal statements of multiplicative comparisons as multiplication equations.

khanAcademyContent.name: Compare with multiplication word problems
khanAcademyContent.description: Select the equation that can be used to solve a word problem.

khanAcademyContent.name: Compare with multiplication
khanAcademyContent.description: Rewrite multiplication equations as comparisons, and comparisons as equations.

data.description:
Multiply or divide to solve word problems involving multiplicative comparison, e.g., by using drawings and equations with a symbol for the unknown number to represent the problem, distinguishing multiplicative comparison from additive comparison.*

*See Glossary, Table 2

khanAcademyContent.name: Multiplication and division word problems
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice solving multiplication and division word problems. Some problems have remainders.

data.description: Solve multistep word problems posed with whole numbers and having whole-number answers using the four operations, including problems in which remainders must be interpreted. Represent these problems using equations with a letter standing for the unknown quantity. Assess the reasonableness of answers using mental computation and estimation strategies including rounding.

khanAcademyContent.name: Multi-step word problems with whole numbers
khanAcademyContent.description: Solve multi-step word problems, including estimation.  Select the equation that can be used to solve a word problem.

khanAcademyContent.name: Represent multi-step word problems using equations
khanAcademyContent.description: Represent multi-step word problems using equations with a letter standing for the unknown quantity. Equations include addition, subtraction, multiplication, and division.

khanAcademyContent.name: Multi-step estimation word problems
khanAcademyContent.description: Use estimation to solve multi-step word problems involving addition, subtraction, multiplication, and division.

children.name: Gain Familiarity With Factors And Multiples.

data.description: Find all factor pairs for a whole number in the range 1–100. Recognize that a whole number is a multiple of each of its factors. Determine whether a given whole number in the range 1–100 is a multiple of a given one-digit number. Determine whether a given whole number in the range 1–100 is prime or composite.

khanAcademyContent.name: Identify composite numbers
khanAcademyContent.description: Identify composite numbers less than 100.

khanAcademyContent.name: Factor pairs
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice finding factor pairs for whole numbers.

khanAcademyContent.name: Identify factors and multiples
khanAcademyContent.description: Demonstrate understanding of factors and multiples.

khanAcademyContent.name: Identify prime numbers
khanAcademyContent.description: Identify prime numbers less than 100.

children.name: Generate And Analyze Patterns.

data.description: Generate a number or shape pattern that follows a given rule. Identify apparent features of the pattern that were not explicit in the rule itself. For example, given the rule “Add 3” and the starting number 1, generate terms in the resulting sequence and observe that the terms appear to alternate between odd and even numbers. Explain informally why the numbers will continue to alternate in this way.

khanAcademyContent.name: Math patterns 2
khanAcademyContent.description: Generate terms in a pattern when given a rule.  Identify features of a pattern that are not explicit to the rule itself.

children.name: Geometry
Graph Points On The Coordinate Plane To Solve Real-World And Mathematical Problems.

data.description: Use a pair of perpendicular number lines, called axes, to define a coordinate system, with the intersection of the lines (the origin) arranged to coincide with the 0 on each line and a given point in the plane located by using an ordered pair of numbers, called its coordinates. Understand that the first number indicates how far to travel from the origin in the direction of one axis, and the second number indicates how far to travel in the direction of the second axis, with the convention that the names of the two axes and the coordinates correspond (e.g., x-axis and x-coordinate, y-axis and y-coordinate).

khanAcademyContent.name: Graph points
khanAcademyContent.description: Plot a given point on the coordinate plane.

khanAcademyContent.name: Identify points
khanAcademyContent.description: Identify points in the first quadrant of a coordinate plane.

khanAcademyContent.name: Identify coordinates
khanAcademyContent.description: Identify coordinates of points in the first quadrant.

data.description: Represent real world and mathematical problems by graphing points in the first quadrant of the coordinate plane, and interpret coordinate values of points in the context of the situation.

khanAcademyContent.name: Identify coordinates
khanAcademyContent.description: Identify coordinates of points in the first quadrant.

khanAcademyContent.name: Identify points
khanAcademyContent.description: Identify points in the first quadrant of a coordinate plane.

khanAcademyContent.name: Graph points
khanAcademyContent.description: Plot a given point on the coordinate plane.

khanAcademyContent.name: Shapes on the coordinate plane
khanAcademyContent.description: Identify and graph corners on shapes graphed in the first quadrant of a coordinate plane.

khanAcademyContent.name: Coordinate plane word problems (quadrant 1)
khanAcademyContent.description: See how we can use the axes on the coordinate plane to represent quantities.

khanAcademyContent.name: Distance between points in first quadrant
khanAcademyContent.description: Graph and find the distance between point in first quadrant of coordinate plane.

children.name: Classify Two-Dimensional Figures Into Categories Based On Their Properties.

data.description: Understand that attributes belonging to a category of two- dimensional figures also belong to all subcategories of that category. For example, all rectangles have four right angles and squares are rectangles, so all squares have four right angles.

khanAcademyContent.name: Properties of shapes
khanAcademyContent.description: Identify and compare shapes based on their attributes.  Shapes include triangle types, quadrilateral types, pentagons, and hexagons.

data.description: Classify two-dimensional figures in a hierarchy based on properties.

khanAcademyContent.name: Identify quadrilaterals
khanAcademyContent.description: Identify squares, rectangles, and rhombuses.

khanAcademyContent.name: Quadrilateral types
khanAcademyContent.description: Identify quadrilaterals based on pictures or attributes.  Quadrilaterals included are parallelograms, rhombuses, rectangles, and squares.

khanAcademyContent.name: Properties of shapes
khanAcademyContent.description: Identify and compare shapes based on their attributes.  Shapes include triangle types, quadrilateral types, pentagons, and hexagons.

children.name: Measurement And Data
Convert Like Measurement Units Within A Given Measurement System.

data.description: Convert among different-sized standard measurement units within a given measurement system (e.g., convert 5 cm to 0.05 m), and use these conversions in solving multi-step, real world problems.

khanAcademyContent.name: Convert units word problems (US customary)
khanAcademyContent.description: Solve word problems that involve converting between US customary measures of distance, volume, and mass.

khanAcademyContent.name: Convert units (US customary)
khanAcademyContent.description: Convert between US customary measures of distance, volume, and mass.

khanAcademyContent.name: Convert units (metrics)
khanAcademyContent.description: Convert between metric measures of distance, volume, and mass.

khanAcademyContent.name: Convert units word problems (metric)
khanAcademyContent.description: Solve word problems that involve converting between metric measures of distance, volume, and mass, as well as measures of time.

children.name: Represent And Interpret Data.

data.description: Make a line plot to display a data set of measurements in fractions of a unit (1/2, 1/4, 1/8). Use operations on fractions for this grade to solve problems involving information presented in line plots. For example, given different measurements of liquid in identical beakers, find the amount of liquid each beaker would contain if the total amount in all the beakers were redistributed equally.

khanAcademyContent.name: Interpret dot plots with fraction operations
khanAcademyContent.description: Interpret fraction data on dot plots to solve word problems.

children.name: Geometric Measurement: Understand Concepts Of Volume And Relate Volume To Multiplication And To Addition.

data.description: A cube with side length 1 unit, called a “unit cube,” is said to have “one cubic unit” of volume, and can be used to measure volume.
A solid figure which can be packed without gaps or overlaps using n unit cubes is said to have a volume of n cubic units.
Recognize volume as an attribute of solid figures and understand concepts of volume measurement.
Measure volumes by counting unit cubes, using cubic cm, cubic in, cubic ft, and improvised units.

khanAcademyContent.name: Compare volumes with unit cubes
khanAcademyContent.description: Recognize volume as an attribute of solid figures and understand concepts of volume measurement.

khanAcademyContent.name: Volume with unit cubes 1
khanAcademyContent.description: Find volume of 3-dimensional figures by counting unit cubes.

data.description: Find the volume of a right rectangular prism with whole-number side lengths by packing it with unit cubes, and show that the volume is the same as would be found by multiplying the edge lengths, equivalently by multiplying the height by the area of the base. Represent threefold whole-number products as volumes, e.g., to represent the associative property of multiplication.
Apply the formulas V=l×w×handV=b×h for rectangular prisms to find volumes of right rectangular prisms with whole- number edge lengths in the context of solving real world and mathematical problems.

Recognize volume as additive. Find volumes of solid figures composed of two non-overlapping right rectangular prisms by adding the volumes of the non-overlapping parts, applying this technique to solve real world problems.
Relate volume to the operations of multiplication and addition and solve real world and mathematical problems involving volume.

khanAcademyContent.name: Volume 1
khanAcademyContent.description: Find volume of a rectangular prism with labeled side lengths.  Find a missing side length on a rectangular prism when given the volume.

khanAcademyContent.name: Decompose figures to find volume (unit cubes)
khanAcademyContent.description: Find the volume of irregular 3D figures made up of unit cubes by dividing the figures into rectangular prisms and finding the volume of each part.

khanAcademyContent.name: Decompose figures to find volume
khanAcademyContent.description: Find the volume of irregular 3D figures by dividing the figures into rectangular prisms and finding the volume of each part.

khanAcademyContent.name: Compare volumes with unit cubes
khanAcademyContent.description: Recognize volume as an attribute of solid figures and understand concepts of volume measurement.

khanAcademyContent.name: Volume word problems
khanAcademyContent.description: Find volume of rectangular prisms to solve word problems.

children.name: Number And Operations In Base Ten
Understand The Place Value System.

data.description: Recognize that in a multi-digit number, a digit in one place represents 10 times as much as it represents in the place to its right and 1/10 of what it represents in the place to its left.

khanAcademyContent.name: Value of a digit
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice identifying the value of one of the digits in a decimal number. For example, the 3 in 4.563 has a value of 0.003.

khanAcademyContent.name: Regroup whole numbers
khanAcademyContent.description: Regroup numbers in each place value (e.g., regroup 1 ten as 10 ones) to express whole numbers in different ways.

khanAcademyContent.name: Compare decimal place value
khanAcademyContent.description: Compare 2 numbers to thousandths based on meanings of the digits in each place.

data.description: Explain patterns in the number of zeros of the product when multiplying a number by powers of 10, and explain patterns in the placement of the decimal point when a decimal is multiplied or divided by a power of 10. Use whole-number exponents to denote powers of 10.

khanAcademyContent.name: Multiply and divide whole numbers by 10, 100, and 1000
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice multiplying and dividing whole numbers by 10, 100, and 1000.

khanAcademyContent.name: Multiply and divide decimals by 10
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice multiplying and dividing decimal numbers by 10.

khanAcademyContent.name: Powers of ten
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice evaluating powers of ten.

khanAcademyContent.name: Multiply and divide decimals by 10, 100, and 1000
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice multiplying and dividing decimals by 10, 100, and 1000. For example, divide 31.4 by 100 to get 0.314.

khanAcademyContent.name: Understanding moving the decimal
khanAcademyContent.description: Give the number of tens a number is being multiplied or divided by when the decimal is moved to the left or right.

khanAcademyContent.name: Multiply and divide by powers of 10
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice multiplying and dividing by powers of 10.

data.description: Read and write decimals to thousandths using base-ten numerals, number names, and expanded form, e.g., 347.392 = 3 × 100 + 4 × 10 + 7 × 1 + 3 × (1/10) + 9 × (1/100) + 2 × (1/1000).
Compare two decimals to thousandths based on meanings of the digits in each place, using >, =, and < symbols to record the results of comparisons.
Read, write, and compare decimals to thousandths.

khanAcademyContent.name: Decimals in written form
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice converting decimals between standard form and written form.

khanAcademyContent.name: Place value names
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice identifying place value names for decimal numbers. For example, the 3 in 4.563 is in the thousandths place.

khanAcademyContent.name: Compare decimals word problems
khanAcademyContent.description: Solve word problems by comparing decimals

khanAcademyContent.name: Compare decimals challenge
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice decimal comparison problems that stretch your place value understanding.

khanAcademyContent.name: Regroup decimals
khanAcademyContent.description: Regroup numbers in each place value (e.g., regroup 1 ten as 10 ones) to express decimals in different ways.

khanAcademyContent.name: Compare decimals through thousandths
khanAcademyContent.description: Compare 2 decimals with digits up to the thousandths using >, <, and = symbols.

khanAcademyContent.name: Decimals in expanded form
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice converting decimals between standard form and expanded form.

khanAcademyContent.name: Order decimals
khanAcademyContent.description: Order 3 decimals with digits up to the thousandths from least to greatest.

data.description: Use place value understanding to round decimals to any place.

khanAcademyContent.name: Round decimals challenge
khanAcademyContent.description: Round decimals using number lines.  Select numbers that round to a given value.

khanAcademyContent.name: Round decimals using a number line
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice using a number line to round decimal numbers.

khanAcademyContent.name: Round decimals
khanAcademyContent.description: Round decimals and whole numbers to the nearest thousand, hundred, ten, one, tenth, or hundredth.

khanAcademyContent.name: Round decimals word problems
khanAcademyContent.description: Solve word problems by rounding decimals

children.name: Perform Operations With Multi-Digit Whole Numbers And With Decimals To Hundredths.

data.description: Fluently multiply multi-digit whole numbers using the standard algorithm.

khanAcademyContent.name: Multiply by taking out factors of 10
khanAcademyContent.description: Multiply numbers like 900 x 1000

khanAcademyContent.name: Estimate multi-digit multiplication problems
khanAcademyContent.description: Use estimation to find a reasonable solution to multi-digit multiplication problems.

khanAcademyContent.name: Multi-digit multiplication
khanAcademyContent.description: Multiply 2-3 digits by 3-4 digits with carrying.

data.description: Find whole-number quotients of whole numbers with up to four-digit dividends and two-digit divisors, using strategies based on place value, the properties of operations, and/or the relationship between multiplication and division. Illustrate and explain the calculation by using equations, rectangular arrays, and/or area models.

khanAcademyContent.name: Basic multi-digit division
khanAcademyContent.description: Divide numbers like 105÷21 or 119÷17

khanAcademyContent.name: Divide by taking out factors of 10
khanAcademyContent.description: Divide numbers like 2400÷30.

khanAcademyContent.name: Estimate multi-digit division problems
khanAcademyContent.description: Use estimation to find a reasonable solution to multi-digit division problems.

data.description: Add, subtract, multiply, and divide decimals to hundredths, using concrete models or drawings and strategies based on place value, properties of operations, and/or the relationship between addition and subtraction; relate the strategy to a written method and explain the reasoning used.

khanAcademyContent.name: Estimating with multiplying decimals
khanAcademyContent.description: For example, estimate 6.74 x 1.98 to be 14.

khanAcademyContent.name: Estimating with adding decimals
khanAcademyContent.description: For example, estimate 12.93 + 6.1 to be 19.

khanAcademyContent.name: Subtract decimals visually
khanAcademyContent.description: Use tenths and hundredths charts to subtract decimals.

khanAcademyContent.name: Add decimals like 5.53+6.1
khanAcademyContent.description: Add whole numbers, tenths, and hundredths like 60+2.57 or 5.53+3.1

khanAcademyContent.name: Multiply decimals like 0.6x0.4
khanAcademyContent.description: Multiply tenths like 0.6 x 0.4

khanAcademyContent.name: Add decimals like 47.75+11.98
khanAcademyContent.description: Add more challenging whole numbers, tenths, and hundredths like 5.7+4.51 or 47.75+11.98

khanAcademyContent.name: Divide decimals like 1.32÷0.12
khanAcademyContent.description: More challenging division with decimals like 14÷0.7 or 1.32÷0.12.

khanAcademyContent.name: Subtract decimals like 0.9-0.7
khanAcademyContent.description: Subtract tenths like 0.9-0.7

khanAcademyContent.name: Subtract decimals like 67.89-6
khanAcademyContent.description: Subtract larger whole numbers, tenths, and hundredths like 67.89-6 or 35.65-17.34

khanAcademyContent.name: Add decimals visually
khanAcademyContent.description: Use tenths and hundredths charts to add decimals.

khanAcademyContent.name: Divide decimals like 16.8÷40 by factoring out a 10
khanAcademyContent.description: Dividing decimals where we can factor a 10 out of the divisor like 9÷30

khanAcademyContent.name: Subtract decimals like 15-7.45
khanAcademyContent.description: More challenging subtraction problems with whole numbers, tenths, and hundredths like 15-7.45 or 12.19-7.68

khanAcademyContent.name: Multiply decimals like 1.7x0.12
khanAcademyContent.description: Multiply numbers with tenths and hundredths like 3.1x3.3 or 1.7x0.12

khanAcademyContent.name: Add decimals like 0.7+0.5
khanAcademyContent.description: Add tenths like 0.7 + 0.5

khanAcademyContent.name: Divide whole numbers like 80÷200 to get a decimal
khanAcademyContent.description: Dividing larger whole numbers by whole numbers to get a decimal like 80÷200

khanAcademyContent.name: Divide decimals like 1.86÷2
khanAcademyContent.description: Dividing decimals by whole numbers like 2.5÷5 or 1.86÷2

khanAcademyContent.name: Multiply decimals like 0.56x4
khanAcademyContent.description: Multiply decimals and whole numbers like 8x0.2 or 0.56x4

khanAcademyContent.name: Divide decimals visually
khanAcademyContent.description: Use tenths and hundredths charts and number lines to divide decimals.

khanAcademyContent.name: Subtract decimals like 56.8-17.9
khanAcademyContent.description: Subtract trickier numbers with tenths like 56.8-17.9

khanAcademyContent.name: Add decimals like 40.1+7.6
khanAcademyContent.description: Add larger numbers with tenths like 40.1+7.6

khanAcademyContent.name: Estimating with dividing decimals
khanAcademyContent.description: For example, estimate 5609 ÷ 7 to be 800.

khanAcademyContent.name: Estimating with subtracting decimals
khanAcademyContent.description: For example, estimate 9.72 - 1.9 to be 8.

khanAcademyContent.name: Divide decimals and whole numbers by 0.1 or 0.01
khanAcademyContent.description: Dividing numbers by 0.1 or 0.01 like 10÷0.1 or 5.3÷0.01

khanAcademyContent.name: Subtract decimals like 0.75-0.56
khanAcademyContent.description: Subtract hundredths like 0.75-0.56

khanAcademyContent.name: Subtract decimals like 78.4-3
khanAcademyContent.description: Subtract larger whole numbers and tenths like 78.4-3

khanAcademyContent.name: Divide whole numbers like 7÷5 to get a decimal
khanAcademyContent.description: Dividing whole numbers to get a decimal quotient like 15÷6=2.5

khanAcademyContent.name: Subtract decimals like 1.6-0.3
khanAcademyContent.description: Subtract small whole numbers and tenths like 1.6-0.3

khanAcademyContent.name: Multiply decimals visually
khanAcademyContent.description: Use tenths and hundredths charts and number lines to multiply decimals.

khanAcademyContent.name: Divide decimals like 0.72÷0.08
khanAcademyContent.description: Dividing tenths by tenths like 0.6÷0.2.

khanAcademyContent.name: Add decimals like 4+5.7
khanAcademyContent.description: Add whole numbers and tenths like 4 + 5.7

khanAcademyContent.name: Add decimals like 0.76+0.21
khanAcademyContent.description: Add hundredths like 0.76+0.21

khanAcademyContent.name: Divide whole numbers like 63÷12 to get a decimal
khanAcademyContent.description: Dividing larger whole numbers to get a decimal quotient like 63÷12=5.25

khanAcademyContent.name: Subtract decimals like 0.6-0.43
khanAcademyContent.description: Subtract small whole numbers, tenths, and hundredths like 0.6-0.43 or 1.58-0.5

children.name: Number And Operations-Fractions
Use Equivalent Fractions As A Strategy To Add And Subtract Fractions.

data.description: Add and subtract fractions with unlike denominators (including mixed numbers) by replacing given fractions with equivalent fractions in such a way as to produce an equivalent sum or difference of fractions with like denominators. For example, 2/3 + 5/4 = 8/12 + 15/12 = 23/12. (In general, a/b + c/d = (ad + bc)/bd.)

khanAcademyContent.name: Add and subtract fractions challenge
khanAcademyContent.description: Challenge problems involving adding and subtracting fractions that have unlike denominators.

khanAcademyContent.name: Visually add and subtract fractions
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice adding and subtracting fractions that have different denominators. Problems have fraction diagrams.

khanAcademyContent.name: Subtracting fractions with unlike denominators
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice subtracting fractions that have different denominators.

khanAcademyContent.name: Add and subtract mixed numbers with unlike denominators (regrouping)
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice adding and subtracting mixed numbers with different denominators. Regrouping required.

khanAcademyContent.name: Add fractions with unlike denominators
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice adding fractions that have different denominators.

khanAcademyContent.name: Equivalent expressions with common denominators
khanAcademyContent.description: Rewrite a fraction addition problem so the fractions have common denominators.

khanAcademyContent.name: Add and subtract mixed numbers with unlike denominators (no regrouping)
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice adding and subtracting mixed numbers with different denominators. No regrouping required.

data.description: Solve word problems involving addition and subtraction of fractions referring to the same whole, including cases of unlike denominators, e.g., by using visual fraction models or equations to represent the problem. Use benchmark fractions and number sense of fractions to estimate mentally and assess the reasonableness of answers. For example, recognize an incorrect result 2/5 + 1/2 = 3/7, by observing that 3/7 < 1/2.

khanAcademyContent.name: Add and subtract fractions word problems
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice solving fraction addition and subtraction word problems. The fractions in these problems have unlike denominators.

children.name: Apply And Extend Previous Understandings Of Multiplication And Division To Multiply And Divide Fractions.

data.description: Interpret a fraction as division of the numerator by the denominator (a/b = a ÷ b). Solve word problems involving division of whole numbers leading to answers in the form of fractions or mixed numbers, e.g., by using visual fraction models or equations to represent the problem. For example, interpret 3/4 as the result of dividing 3 by 4, noting that 3/4 multiplied by 4 equals 3, and that when 3 wholes are shared equally among 4 people each person has a share of size 3/4. If 9 people want to share a 50-pound sack of rice equally by weight, how many pounds of rice should each person get? Between what two whole numbers does your answer lie?

khanAcademyContent.name: Fractions as division word problems
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice word problems that involve using the fraction bar as division.

khanAcademyContent.name: Fractions as division
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice understanding that the fraction bar really means division.

data.description: Interpret the product (a/b) × q as a parts of a partition of q into b equal parts; equivalently, as the result of a sequence of operations a × q ÷ b. For example, use a visual fraction model to show (2/3) × 4 = 8/3, and create a story context for this equation. Do the same with (2/3) × (4/5) = 8/15. (In general, (a/b) × (c/d) = ac/bd.)

Find the area of a rectangle with fractional side lengths by tiling it with unit squares of the appropriate unit fraction side lengths, and show that the area is the same as would be found by multiplying the side lengths. Multiply fractional side lengths to find areas of rectangles, and represent fraction products as rectangular areas.
Apply and extend previous understandings of multiplication to multiply a fraction or whole number by a fraction.

khanAcademyContent.name: Multiply fractions and whole numbers visually
khanAcademyContent.description: Use area models, number lines, and tape diagrams to multiply a whole number times a fraction.

khanAcademyContent.name: Multiply mixed numbers
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice multiplying mixed numbers.

khanAcademyContent.name: Area of rectangles with fraction side lengths
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice computing the areas of rectangles that have fractional side lengths.

khanAcademyContent.name: Multiplying fractions with visuals
khanAcademyContent.description: Use area models and tape diagrams to multiply a fraction times a fraction.

khanAcademyContent.name: Multiply fractions and whole numbers
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice multiplying a whole number times a fraction.

khanAcademyContent.name: Multiplying fractions
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice multiplying two fractions.

data.description: Comparing the size of a product to the size of one factor on the basis of the size of the other factor, without performing the indicated multiplication.

Explaining why multiplying a given number by a fraction greater than 1 results in a product greater than the given number (recognizing multiplication by whole numbers greater than 1 as a familiar case); explaining why multiplying a given number by a fraction less than 1 results in a product smaller than the given number; and relating the principle of fraction equivalence a/b = (n×a)/(n×b) to the effect of multiplying a/b by 1.
Interpret multiplication as scaling (resizing), by:

khanAcademyContent.name: Fraction multiplication as scaling
khanAcademyContent.description: Interpret how multiplying by a fraction greater or less than 1 affects the product.

data.description: Solve real world problems involving multiplication of fractions and mixed numbers, e.g., by using visual fraction models or equations to represent the problem.

khanAcademyContent.name: Interpret multiplying fraction and whole number word problems
khanAcademyContent.description: Solve word problems involving multiplication of a fraction by a whole number.  Then interpret the solution by, for example, determining between which two whole numbers the solution falls.

khanAcademyContent.name: Multiply fractions and whole numbers word problems
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice solving multiplication word problems that include whole numbers and fractions.

khanAcademyContent.name: Multiply fractions word problems
khanAcademyContent.description: Solve and interpret fraction multiplication word problems.

data.description: Interpret division of a unit fraction by a non-zero whole number, and compute such quotients. For example, create a story context for (1/3) ÷ 4, and use a visual fraction model to show the quotient. Use the relationship between multiplication and division to explain that (1/3) ÷ 4 = 1/12 because (1/12) × 4 = 1/3.

Interpret division of a whole number by a unit fraction, and compute such quotients. For example, create a story context for 4 ÷ (1/5), and use a visual fraction model to show the quotient. Use the relationship between multiplication and division to explain that 4 ÷ (1/5) = 20 because 20 × (1/5) = 4.

Solve real world problems involving division of unit fractions by non-zero whole numbers and division of whole numbers by unit fractions, e.g., by using visual fraction models and equations to represent the problem. For example, how much chocolate will each person get if 3 people share 1/2 lb of chocolate equally? How many 1/3-cup servings are in 2 cups of raisins?

Apply and extend previous understandings of division to divide unit fractions by whole numbers and whole numbers by unit fractions.*

*Students able to multiply fractions in general can develop strategies to divide fractions in general, by reasoning about the relationship between multiplication and division. But division of a fraction by a fraction is not a requirement at this grade.

khanAcademyContent.name: Dividing whole numbers by unit fractions
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice dividing a whole number by a unit fraction.

khanAcademyContent.name: Dividing whole numbers by unit fractions visually
khanAcademyContent.description: Learn how to divide whole number by unit fractions with visual models.

khanAcademyContent.name: Dividing unit fractions by whole numbers visually
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice dividing unit fractions by whole numbers with visual models.

khanAcademyContent.name: Divide fractions and whole numbers word problems
khanAcademyContent.description: Solve and interpret division word problems that include whole numbers and fractions.

khanAcademyContent.name: Dividing unit fractions by whole numbers
khanAcademyContent.description: Divide a unit fraction by a whole number.

children.name: Operations And Algebraic Thinking
Write And Interpret Numerical Expressions.

data.description: Use parentheses, brackets, or braces in numerical expressions, and evaluate expressions with these symbols.

khanAcademyContent.name: Evaluate expressions with parentheses
khanAcademyContent.description: Solve multi-step expressions with parentheses.  Place parentheses in an expression to make the expression equivalent to a given number.

data.description: Write simple expressions that record calculations with numbers, and interpret numerical expressions without evaluating them. For example, express the calculation “add 8 and 7, then multiply by 2” as 2 × (8 + 7). Recognize that 3 × (18932 + 921) is three times as large as 18932 + 921, without having to calculate the indicated sum or product.

khanAcademyContent.name: Create expressions with parentheses
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice creating expressions with parentheses from real-world contexts.

khanAcademyContent.name: Translate expressions with parentheses
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice changing expressions from words to math.

children.name: Analyze Patterns And Relationships.

data.description: Generate two numerical patterns using two given rules. Identify apparent relationships between corresponding terms. Form ordered pairs consisting of corresponding terms from the two patterns, and graph the ordered pairs on a coordinate plane. For example, given the rule “Add 3” and the starting number 0, and given the rule “Add 6” and the starting number 0, generate terms in the resulting sequences, and observe that the terms in one sequence are twice the corresponding terms in the other sequence. Explain informally why this is so.

khanAcademyContent.name: Graphs of rules that relate 2 variables
khanAcademyContent.description: Complete a table from a given rule. Then, plot points from the table on a coordinate plane.

khanAcademyContent.name: Identify points on a line
khanAcademyContent.description: Identify the coordinates of points on a line and match a table of x- and y-coordinates to a line.

khanAcademyContent.name: Tables from rules that relate 2 variables
khanAcademyContent.description: Complete a table, identify coordinates, and identify inputs and outputs when given a two-variable rule.

khanAcademyContent.name: Relationships between 2 patterns
khanAcademyContent.description: Generate patterns using given rules. Identify relationships between terms. Graph ordered pairs consisting of corresponding terms from the patterns.

khanAcademyContent.name: Write rules that relate 2 variables
khanAcademyContent.description: Identify the rule that describes the relationship between the x- and y-coordinates in a table or set of coordinates.

children.name: Expressions And Equations
Apply And Extend Previous Understandings Of Arithmetic To Algebraic Expressions.

data.description: Write and evaluate numerical expressions involving whole-number exponents.

khanAcademyContent.name: Exponents (basic)
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice taking exponents of whole numbers. All exponents in these problems are either positive or zero.

khanAcademyContent.name: Powers of fractions
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice evaluating exponents that have fractional bases.

khanAcademyContent.name: Variable expressions with exponents
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice evaluating expressions with exponents by substituting values for the variables.

khanAcademyContent.name: Order of operations challenge
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice solving more challenging problems using the order of operations.

khanAcademyContent.name: Exponents
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice solving more challenging exponents problems. All exponents in these problems are either positive or zero.

data.description: Write expressions that record operations with numbers and with letters standing for numbers. For example, express the calculation “Subtract y from 5” as 5 – y.

Identify parts of an expression using mathematical terms (sum, term, product, factor, quotient, coefficient); view one or more parts of an expression as a single entity. For example, describe the expression 2 (8 + 7) as a product of two factors; view (8 + 7) as both a single entity and a sum of two terms.

Evaluate expressions at specific values of their variables. Include expressions that arise from formulas used in real-world problems. Perform arithmetic operations, including those involving whole- number exponents, in the conventional order when there are no parentheses to specify a particular order (Order of Operations). For example, use the formulas V = s3 and A = 6 s2 to find the volume and surface area of a cube with sides of length s = 1/2.
Write, read, and evaluate expressions in which letters stand for numbers.

khanAcademyContent.name: Writing basic expressions word problems
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice writing basic algebraic expressions to model real-world situations.

khanAcademyContent.name: Evaluating expressions with multiple variables
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice evaluating expressions in two variables by plugging in values for the variables.

khanAcademyContent.name: Order of operations challenge
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice solving more challenging problems using the order of operations.

khanAcademyContent.name: Evaluating expressions with one variable
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice plugging in a value for the variable in an equation. These are introductory problems, so the expressions aren't too complicated.

khanAcademyContent.name: Writing expressions with variables
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice writing algebraic expressions to match verbal descriptions of mathematical operations.

khanAcademyContent.name: Order of operations
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice evaluating expressions using the order of operations.

khanAcademyContent.name: Evaluating expressions with variables word problems
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice plugging in values to evaluate real-world algebraic expressions. These are introductory problems, so the expressions aren't too complicated.

khanAcademyContent.name: Evaluating expressions with multiple variables: fractions & decimals
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice evaluating expressions in two variables by plugging in values for the variables. These problems include some fractions and decimals.

khanAcademyContent.name: Expression value intuition
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice thinking about how the values of expressions change as the values of their variables change.

khanAcademyContent.name: Parts of algebraic expressions
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice identifying the following parts of algebraic expressions: sum, product, difference, quotient, coefficient, factor, term, and variable.

khanAcademyContent.name: Writing basic expressions with variables
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice writing basic algebraic expressions to match verbal descriptions of mathematical operations.

data.description: Apply the properties of operations to generate equivalent expressions.

khanAcademyContent.name: Distributive property with variables
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice applying the distributive property to algebraic expressions.

khanAcademyContent.name: Combining like terms
khanAcademyContent.description: Simplify algebraic expressions by combining like terms.

khanAcademyContent.name: Factor with the distributive property (no variables)
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice applying the distributive property to factor numerical expressions (no variables).

khanAcademyContent.name: Equivalent expressions
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice determining whether or not two algebraic expressions are equivalent by manipulating the expressions. These problems require you to combine like terms and apply the distributive property.

khanAcademyContent.name: Factor with distributive property (variables)
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice applying the distributive property to factor algebraic expressions.

data.description: Identify when two expressions are equivalent (i.e., when the two expressions name the same number regardless of which value is substituted into them). For example, the expressions y + y + y and 3y are equivalent because they name the same number regardless of which number y stands for.

khanAcademyContent.name: Distributive property with variables
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice applying the distributive property to algebraic expressions.

khanAcademyContent.name: Factor with distributive property (variables)
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice applying the distributive property to factor algebraic expressions.

khanAcademyContent.name: Combining like terms
khanAcademyContent.description: Simplify algebraic expressions by combining like terms.

khanAcademyContent.name: Equivalent expressions
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice determining whether or not two algebraic expressions are equivalent by manipulating the expressions. These problems require you to combine like terms and apply the distributive property.

children.name: Reason About And Solve One-Variable Equations And Inequalities.

data.description: Understand solving an equation or inequality as a process of answering a question: which values from a specified set, if any, make the equation or inequality true? Use substitution to determine whether a given number in a specified set makes an equation or inequality true.

khanAcademyContent.name: Testing solutions to inequalities (basic)
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice plugging in values to inequalities, like x>5, and checking to see if the inequalities hold true.

khanAcademyContent.name: Identify equations from visual models (tape diagrams)
khanAcademyContent.description: Identify the equation represented by a tape diagram. Then, solve for the unknown in the equation.

khanAcademyContent.name: Testing solutions to inequalities
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice plugging in values to inequalities, like 2x<14, and checking to see if the inequalities hold true.

khanAcademyContent.name: Solve equations from visual models
khanAcademyContent.description: Use a visual model of an equation to solve for the unknown in the equation.

khanAcademyContent.name: Identify equations from visual models (hanger diagrams)
khanAcademyContent.description: Identify the equation represented by a  hanger diagram. Then, solve for the unknown in the equation.

khanAcademyContent.name: Testing solutions to equations
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice plugging in values to equations and checking to see if the equations hold true.

data.description: Use variables to represent numbers and write expressions when solving a real-world or mathematical problem; understand that a variable can represent an unknown number, or, depending on the purpose at hand, any number in a specified set.

khanAcademyContent.name: Model with one-step equations
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice writing basic equations to model real-world situations.

khanAcademyContent.name: Translate one-step equations and solve
khanAcademyContent.description: Write a statement like, '8 more than y is 17' as an equation. Then, solve for the variable.

khanAcademyContent.name: Model with one-step equations and solve
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice writing basic equations to model real-world situations. Then solve for the variable.

data.description: Solve real-world and mathematical problems by writing and solving equations of the form x + p = q and px = q for cases in which p, q and x are all nonnegative rational numbers.

khanAcademyContent.name: Testing solutions to equations
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice plugging in values to equations and checking to see if the equations hold true.

khanAcademyContent.name: One-step multiplication & division equations
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice solving equations in one step by multiplying or dividing a value from both sides.

khanAcademyContent.name: One-step multiplication & division equations: fractions & decimals
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice solving equations in one step by multiplying or dividing a number from both sides. These problems involve decimals and fractions.

khanAcademyContent.name: One-step addition & subtraction equations
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice solving equations in one step by adding or subtracting the same value from both sides.

khanAcademyContent.name: Translate one-step equations and solve
khanAcademyContent.description: Write a statement like, '8 more than y is 17' as an equation. Then, solve for the variable.

khanAcademyContent.name: Solve equations from visual models
khanAcademyContent.description: Use a visual model of an equation to solve for the unknown in the equation.

khanAcademyContent.name: Identify equations from visual models (tape diagrams)
khanAcademyContent.description: Identify the equation represented by a tape diagram. Then, solve for the unknown in the equation.

khanAcademyContent.name: Find the mistake in one-step equations
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice spotting the mistake in someone else's work as they attempt to solve one-step equations.

khanAcademyContent.name: Model with one-step equations
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice writing basic equations to model real-world situations.

khanAcademyContent.name: Identify equations from visual models (hanger diagrams)
khanAcademyContent.description: Identify the equation represented by a  hanger diagram. Then, solve for the unknown in the equation.

khanAcademyContent.name: Model with one-step equations and solve
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice writing basic equations to model real-world situations. Then solve for the variable.

khanAcademyContent.name: Inequalities word problems
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice writing inequalities with variables to describe real-world situations.

khanAcademyContent.name: One-step addition & subtraction equations: fractions & decimals
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice solving equations in one step by adding or subtracting a number from both sides. These problems involve decimals and fractions.

data.description: Write an inequality of the form x > c or x < c to represent a constraint or condition in a real-world or mathematical problem. Recognize that inequalities of the form x > c or x < c have infinitely many solutions; represent solutions of such inequalities on number line diagrams.

khanAcademyContent.name: Graphing basic inequalities
khanAcademyContent.description: Identify graphs of inequalities like x>8 or x<-4.

khanAcademyContent.name: Inequalities word problems
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice writing inequalities with variables to describe real-world situations.

children.name: Represent And Analyze Quantitative Relationships Between Dependent And Independent Variables.

data.description: Use variables to represent two quantities in a real-world problem that change in relationship to one another; write an equation to express one quantity, thought of as the dependent variable, in terms of the other quantity, thought of as the independent variable. Analyze the relationship between the dependent and independent variables using graphs and tables, and relate these to the equation. For example, in a problem involving motion at constant speed, list and graph ordered pairs of distances and times, and write the equation d = 65t to represent the relationship between distance and time.

khanAcademyContent.name: Relationships between quantities in equations and graphs
khanAcademyContent.description: Use variables to represent two quantities in a real-world problem that change in relationship to one another; write an equation to express one quantity in terms of the other quantity. Then, analyze the relationship between the variables using graphs and tables, and relate these to the equation.

khanAcademyContent.name: Tables from equations with 2 variables
khanAcademyContent.description: Complete a table and identify coordinates when given a two-variable equation, such as y=2x+4.

khanAcademyContent.name: Independent versus dependent variables
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice figuring out if a variable is dependent or independent.

khanAcademyContent.name: Match equations to coordinates on a line
khanAcademyContent.description: Identify the coordinates or line that matches a two-variable equation. Also, identify the corresponding equation when given a line and coordinates.

children.name: Geometry
Solve Real-World And Mathematical Problems Involving Area, Surface Area, And Volume.

data.description: Find the area of right triangles, other triangles, special quadrilaterals, and polygons by composing into rectangles or decomposing into triangles and other shapes; apply these techniques in the context of solving real-world and mathematical problems.

khanAcademyContent.name: Area of right triangles
khanAcademyContent.description: Find the area of right triangles

khanAcademyContent.name: Find missing length when given area of a triangle
khanAcademyContent.description: Find the base or height of a triangle when given the other and the area.

khanAcademyContent.name: Area of triangles
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice finding the area of right, acute, and obtuse triangles.

khanAcademyContent.name: Area of trapezoids
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice finding the areas of trapezoids.

khanAcademyContent.name: Area of parallelograms
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice finding the area of parallelograms given base and height.

khanAcademyContent.name: Find base and height on a triangle
khanAcademyContent.description: Identify the height of a triangle when given the base.

khanAcademyContent.name: Area of composite shapes
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice finding the areas of complex shapes that are composed of smaller shapes.

khanAcademyContent.name: Find missing length when given area of a parallelogram
khanAcademyContent.description: Find the base or height of a parallelogram when given the other and the area.

khanAcademyContent.name: Area challenge
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice solving problems involving triangles, parallelograms, and composite figures. Exercises include decimals, fractions, and word problems. Area of circles is not included.

data.description: Find the volume of a right rectangular prism with fractional edge lengths by packing it with unit cubes of the appropriate unit fraction edge lengths, and show that the volume is the same as would be found by multiplying the edge lengths of the prism. Apply the formulas V = l w h and V = b h to find volumes of right rectangular prisms with fractional edge lengths in the context of solving real-world and mathematical problems.

khanAcademyContent.name: Volume by multiplying area of base times height
khanAcademyContent.description: Find the volume of a rectangular prism by multiplying the area of the base by the height of the figure. Measurements include fractions.

khanAcademyContent.name: Volume with cubes with fraction lengths
khanAcademyContent.description: Find volume of rectangular prisms by using cubes with fraction side lengths.

khanAcademyContent.name: Volume word problems: fractions & decimals
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice solving volume word problems involving objects like fish tanks, truck beds, and refrigerators.

khanAcademyContent.name: Volume with fractions
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice finding the volume of rectangular prisms that have fractional side lengths.

data.description: Draw polygons in the coordinate plane given coordinates for the vertices; use coordinates to find the length of a side joining points with the same first coordinate or the same second coordinate. Apply these techniques in the context of solving real-world and mathematical problems.

khanAcademyContent.name: Drawing polygons with coordinates
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice drawing shapes on the coordinate plane.

khanAcademyContent.name: Quadrilateral problems on the coordinate plane
khanAcademyContent.description: Challenge problems involving the coordinates of the vertices of the quadrilaterals

khanAcademyContent.name: Area and perimeter on the coordinate plane
khanAcademyContent.description: Find the area and perimeter of quadrilaterals using their coordinates.

data.description: Represent three-dimensional figures using nets made up of rectangles and triangles, and use the nets to find the surface area of these figures. Apply these techniques in the context of solving real-world and mathematical problems.

khanAcademyContent.name: Find surface area by adding areas of faces
khanAcademyContent.description: Determine the expression that finds surface area of a 3D shape by adding the area of each face.

khanAcademyContent.name: Surface area using nets
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice using the net of a 3D figure to find surface area.

khanAcademyContent.name: Nets of polyhedra
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice matching 2D nets to the 3D shapes the fold up into.

khanAcademyContent.name: Surface area
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice finding the surface area of 3D objects.

khanAcademyContent.name: Surface area word problems
khanAcademyContent.description: Solve word problems that involve surface area of pyramids and prisms.

children.name: The Number System
Apply And Extend Previous Understandings Of Multiplication And Division To Divide Fractions By Fractions.

data.description: Interpret and compute quotients of fractions, and solve word problems involving division of fractions by fractions, e.g., by using visual fraction models and equations to represent the problem. For example, create a story context for (2/3) ÷ (3/4) and use a visual fraction model to show the quotient; use the relationship between multiplication and division to explain that (2/3) ÷ (3/4) = 8/9 because 3/4 of 8/9 is 2/3. (In general, (a/b) ÷ (c/d) = ad/bc.) How much chocolate will each person get if 3 people share 1/2 lb of chocolate equally? How many 3/4-cup servings are in 2/3 of a cup of yogurt? How wide is a rectangular strip of land with length 3/4 mi and area 1/2 square mi?

khanAcademyContent.name: Divide whole numbers by fractions
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice dividing whole numbers by fractions.

khanAcademyContent.name: Dividing fractions word problems
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice solving word problems by dividing fractions by fractions.

khanAcademyContent.name: Dividing fractions
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice dividing fractions by fractions. No negative numbers are used in this exercise.

khanAcademyContent.name: Divide mixed numbers
khanAcademyContent.description: Divide mixed numbers by fractions, whole numbers, and mixed numbers.

children.name: Compute Fluently With Multi-Digit Numbers And Find Common Factors And Multiples.

data.description: Fluently divide multi-digit numbers using the standard algorithm.

khanAcademyContent.name: Division by 2-digits
khanAcademyContent.description: Divide 3-digit and 4-digit numbers by a 2-digit number without remainders.

khanAcademyContent.name: Multi-digit division
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice dividing multi-digit whole numbers. These problems use remainders.

data.description: Fluently add, subtract, multiply, and divide multi-digit decimals using the standard algorithm for each operation.

khanAcademyContent.name: Multiplying decimals like 2.45x3.6 (standard algorithm)
khanAcademyContent.description: Multiply two numbers.  Factors are written to the ones, tenths, or hundredths place.

khanAcademyContent.name: Subtracting decimals: thousandths
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice subtracting two numbers that are written to the tenths, hundredths, or thousandths place.

khanAcademyContent.name: Adding decimals: thousandths
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice adding two numbers that are written to the tenths, hundredths, or thousandths place.

khanAcademyContent.name: Multiplying decimals like 0.847x3.54 (standard algorithm)
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice multiplying two numbers that are written to the tenths, hundredths, or thousandths place.

khanAcademyContent.name: Multiplying decimals like 4x0.6 (standard algorithm)
khanAcademyContent.description: Multiply a whole number times a decimal written to the tenths or hundredths place.

khanAcademyContent.name: Dividing decimals: hundredths
khanAcademyContent.description: Divide two numbers.  Divisors, dividends, and quotients include decimals written to the tenths or hundredths place.  This exercise uses the standard algorithm to find the quotient.

khanAcademyContent.name: Adding & subtracting decimals word problems
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice solving word problems by adding or subtracting decimal numbers.

khanAcademyContent.name: Dividing decimals: thousandths
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice dividing decimal numbers using "long division".

khanAcademyContent.name: Dividing whole numbers like 56÷35 to get a decimal
khanAcademyContent.description: Divide two whole numbers to get a quotient with a decimal.  This exercise uses the standard algorithm to find the quotient.

data.description: Find the greatest common factor of two whole numbers less than or equal to 100 and the least common multiple of two whole numbers less than or equal to 12. Use the distributive property to express a sum of two whole numbers 1–100 with a common factor as a multiple of a sum of two whole numbers with no common factor. For example, express 36 + 8 as 4 (9 + 2).

khanAcademyContent.name: Least common multiple
khanAcademyContent.description: Find the lcm (least common multiple) of pairs of integers.

khanAcademyContent.name: Greatest common factor
khanAcademyContent.description: Find the greatest common factor of 2 or 3 integers.

khanAcademyContent.name: GCF & LCM word problems
khanAcademyContent.description: Solve word problems where you either need to find the GCF or LCM.

children.name: Apply And Extend Previous Understandings Of Numbers To The System Of Rational Numbers.

data.description: Understand that positive and negative numbers are used together to describe quantities having opposite directions or values (e.g., temperature above/below zero, elevation above/below sea level, credits/debits, positive/negative electric charge); use positive and negative numbers to represent quantities in real-world contexts, explaining the meaning of 0 in each situation.

khanAcademyContent.name: Interpreting negative numbers
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice explaining the meaning of negative numbers in different scenarios.

data.description: Recognize opposite signs of numbers as indicating locations on opposite sides of 0 on the number line; recognize that the opposite of the opposite of a number is the number itself, e.g., –(–3) = 3, and that 0 is its own opposite.

Understand signs of numbers in ordered pairs as indicating locations in quadrants of the coordinate plane; recognize that when two ordered pairs differ only by signs, the locations of the points are related by reflections across one or both axes.
Find and position integers and other rational numbers on a horizontal or vertical number line diagram; find and position pairs of integers and other rational numbers on a coordinate plane.

Understand a rational number as a point on the number line. Extend number line diagrams and coordinate axes familiar from previous grades to represent points on the line and in the plane with negative number coordinates.

khanAcademyContent.name: Negative symbol as opposite
khanAcademyContent.description: Recognize the negative sign as meaning the opposite of a number.  Use the negative sign to find the opposites of numbers.  In some items, we will find the opposite of an opposite.

khanAcademyContent.name: Coordinate plane problems in all four quadrants
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice solving word problems by interpreting the meaning of points plotted on an xy coordinate system.

khanAcademyContent.name: Number opposites challenge
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice solving more challenging problems finding the opposites of numbers. Numbers are opposites when they're on opposite sides of the number line the same distance from zero.

khanAcademyContent.name: Quadrants on the coordinate plane
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice graphing points on a coordinate plane and identifying the quadrant or axis where they are located.

khanAcademyContent.name: Rational numbers on the number line
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice placing positive and negative fractions and decimals on the number line.

khanAcademyContent.name: Number opposites
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice finding the opposites of numbers. Numbers are opposites when they're on opposite sides of the number line the same distance from zero.

khanAcademyContent.name: Negative decimals on the number line
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice placing positive and negative decimal numbers on the number line.

khanAcademyContent.name: Points on the coordinate plane
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice graphing points like (-2, 4) on a coordinate plane.

khanAcademyContent.name: Distance between points: vertical or horizontal
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice finding the distance between two points on the coordinate plane that share the same x- or y-coordinate.

khanAcademyContent.name: Negative numbers on the number line
khanAcademyContent.description: Identify positive and negative integers on the number line.

data.description: Interpret statements of inequality as statements about the relative position of two numbers on a number line diagram. For example, interpret –3 > –7 as a statement that –3 is located to the right of –7 on a number line oriented from left to right.
Write, interpret, and explain statements of order for rational numbers in real-world contexts. For example, write –3 oC > –7 oC to express the fact that –3 oC is warmer than –7 oC.

Understand the absolute value of a rational number as its distance from 0 on the number line; interpret absolute value as magnitude for a positive or negative quantity in a real-world situation. For example, for an account balance of –30 dollars, write |–30| = 30 to describe the size of the debt in dollars.
Distinguish comparisons of absolute value from statements about order. For example, recognize that an account balance less than –30 dollars represents a debt greater than 30 dollars.
Understand ordering and absolute value of rational numbers.

khanAcademyContent.name: Ordering negative numbers
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice putting positive and negative numbers in order. For example, -28, 12, -51, and 43.

khanAcademyContent.name: Writing numerical inequalities
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice writing inequalities to describe real-world situations.

khanAcademyContent.name: Finding absolute values
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice finding the absolute value of a number, like -4 or 3.

khanAcademyContent.name: Ordering small negative numbers
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice putting positive and negative numbers in order. For example, --2, 1, -5, and 3.

khanAcademyContent.name: Negative numbers, variables, number line
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice comparing positive and negative numbers by thinking about their positions on the number line. Numbers to the right are greater than numbers to the left.

khanAcademyContent.name: Comparing absolute values challenge
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice more challenging comparison problems with absolute value.

khanAcademyContent.name: Interpreting absolute value
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice understanding the meaning of absolute value in real-world scenarios.

khanAcademyContent.name: Compare and order absolute values
khanAcademyContent.description: Write an inequality to compare absolute values.  Order numbers written in absolute value form from least to greatest.

khanAcademyContent.name: Compare rational numbers
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice putting positive and negative fractions and decimals in order. For example, -12/4, -2.5, and 3.25.

data.description: Solve real-world and mathematical problems by graphing points in all four quadrants of the coordinate plane. Include use of coordinates and absolute value to find distances between points with the same first coordinate or the same second coordinate.

khanAcademyContent.name: Distance between points: vertical or horizontal
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice finding the distance between two points on the coordinate plane that share the same x- or y-coordinate.

khanAcademyContent.name: Coordinate plane problems in all four quadrants
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice solving word problems by interpreting the meaning of points plotted on an xy coordinate system.

children.name: Ratios And Proportional Relationships
Understand Ratio Concepts And Use Ratio Reasoning To Solve Problems.

data.description: Understand the concept of a ratio and use ratio language to describe a ratio relationship between two quantities. For example, “The ratio of wings to beaks in the bird house at the zoo was 2:1, because for every 2 wings there was 1 beak.” “For every vote candidate A received, candidate C received nearly three votes.”

khanAcademyContent.name: Ratios with double number lines
khanAcademyContent.description: Use double number lines to visualize equivalent ratios and describe a ratio relationship between two quantities.

khanAcademyContent.name: Create double number lines
khanAcademyContent.description: Create double numbers lines to interpret ratios.

khanAcademyContent.name: Relate double numbers lines and ratio tables
khanAcademyContent.description: Use double number lines to create ratio tables.

khanAcademyContent.name: Basic ratios
khanAcademyContent.description: Choose the ratio that goes with a picture of two quantities like apples and bananas.

khanAcademyContent.name: Ratios with tape diagrams
khanAcademyContent.description: Use tape diagrams to visualize equivalent ratios and describe a ratio relationship between two quantities.

khanAcademyContent.name: Equivalent ratios
khanAcademyContent.description: Solve simple problems of finding one or more equivalent ratios.

data.description:
Understand the concept of a unit rate a/b associated with a ratio a:b with b ≠ 0, and use rate language in the context of a ratio relationship. For example, “This recipe has a ratio of 3 cups of flour to 4 cups of sugar, so there is 3/4 cup of flour for each cup of sugar.” “We paid \$75 for 15 hamburgers, which is a rate of \$5 per hamburger."*

*Expectations for unit rates in this grade are limited to non-complex fractions.

khanAcademyContent.name: Comparing rates
khanAcademyContent.description: Example problem: Three different stores are offering a deal on pencils. Which store has the lowest price per pencil?

khanAcademyContent.name: Unit rates
khanAcademyContent.description: Find the unit rate for two quantities. For example, if you spend 70 dollars on 8 movie tickets, how much does one movie ticket cost?

khanAcademyContent.name: Rate problems
khanAcademyContent.description: Use rates to solve word problems. For example, Charlie can type 675 words in 9 minutes. How many words can Charlie type in 13 minutes?

data.description: Make tables of equivalent ratios relating quantities with whole- number measurements, find missing values in the tables, and plot the pairs of values on the coordinate plane. Use tables to compare ratios.

Solve unit rate problems including those involving unit pricing and constant speed. For example, if it took 7 hours to mow 4 lawns, then at that rate, how many lawns could be mowed in 35 hours? At what rate were lawns being mowed?
Find a percent of a quantity as a rate per 100 (e.g., 30% of a quantity means 30/100 times the quantity); solve problems involving finding the whole, given a part and the percent.
Use ratio reasoning to convert measurement units; manipulate and transform units appropriately when multiplying or dividing quantities.
Use ratio and rate reasoning to solve real-world and mathematical problems, e.g., by reasoning about tables of equivalent ratios, tape diagrams, double number line diagrams, or equations.

khanAcademyContent.name: Convert fractions to percents
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice writing fractions as percents. For example, convert 2/5 to a percent.

khanAcademyContent.name: Ratios with double number lines
khanAcademyContent.description: Use double number lines to visualize equivalent ratios and describe a ratio relationship between two quantities.

khanAcademyContent.name: Ratio tables
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice filling out tables of equivalent ratios.

khanAcademyContent.name: Equivalent ratio word problems (basic)
khanAcademyContent.description: Solve equivalent ratio word problems.  The numbers used are small enough to solve using discrete diagrams.

khanAcademyContent.name: Relate fractions, decimals, and percents
khanAcademyContent.description: Use fraction models and hundredths grids to identify equivalent fractions, decimals, and percents.

khanAcademyContent.name: Part-part-whole ratios
khanAcademyContent.description: Use a ratio of parts and a total to find the quantities of individual parts.

khanAcademyContent.name: Percent word problems
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice solving word problems involving percents.

khanAcademyContent.name: Intro to percents
khanAcademyContent.description: Use hundreds grids to identify percents.

khanAcademyContent.name: Percents from fraction models
khanAcademyContent.description: Identify percents from fraction models.

khanAcademyContent.name: Percents from tape diagrams
khanAcademyContent.description: Identify percents from tape diagrams.
