khanAcademyContent.name: Convert percents to fractions
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice writing percents as fractions. For example, convert 30% to a simplified fraction.

khanAcademyContent.name: Equivalent ratios
khanAcademyContent.description: Solve simple problems of finding one or more equivalent ratios.

khanAcademyContent.name: Equivalent ratios in the real world
khanAcademyContent.description: This exercise goes beyond solving for equivalent ratios and gets at what it means for ratios to be equivalent.

khanAcademyContent.name: Ratios with tape diagrams
khanAcademyContent.description: Use tape diagrams to visualize equivalent ratios and describe a ratio relationship between two quantities.

khanAcademyContent.name: Understand equivalent ratios in the real world
khanAcademyContent.description: This exercise builds an understanding of what it means for ratios to be equivalent or not be equivalent.

khanAcademyContent.name: Equivalent representations of percent problems
khanAcademyContent.description: Identify expressions that can be used to solve percent problems, like 'What is 5% of 35?'.

khanAcademyContent.name: Ratios and units of measurement
khanAcademyContent.description: Use ratio reasoning to convert measurement units. Transform units appropriately when multiplying or dividing quantities.

khanAcademyContent.name: Relate double numbers lines and ratio tables
khanAcademyContent.description: Use double number lines to create ratio tables.

khanAcademyContent.name: Create double number lines
khanAcademyContent.description: Create double numbers lines to interpret ratios.

khanAcademyContent.name: Finding percents
khanAcademyContent.description: Find a percent of a quantity as a rate per 100; solve problems involving finding the whole, given a part and the percent.

khanAcademyContent.name: Equivalent ratio word problems
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice solving ratio word problems like, "If Ben reads 10 pages in 15 minutes, how long does it take him to read 40 pages?

khanAcademyContent.name: Convert percents to decimals
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice expressing a percent like 12.3% as a decimal.

khanAcademyContent.name: Convert decimals to percents
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice expressing a decimal like 0.546 as a percent.

khanAcademyContent.name: Ratios on coordinate plane
khanAcademyContent.description: Make tables of equivalent ratios and plot the pairs of values on the coordinate plane.

children.name: Statistics And Probability
Develop Understanding Of Statistical Variability.

data.description: Recognize a statistical question as one that anticipates variability in the data related to the question and accounts for it in the answers. For example, “How old am I?” is not a statistical question, but “How old are the students in my school?” is a statistical question because one anticipates variability in students’ ages.

khanAcademyContent.name: Statistical questions
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice spotting the difference between statistical and non-statistical questions.

data.description: Understand that a set of data collected to answer a statistical question has a distribution which can be described by its center, spread, and overall shape.

khanAcademyContent.name: Reading box plots
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice reading information presented in box plots.

khanAcademyContent.name: Shape of distributions
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice explaining the shapes of data distributions. Some distributions are symmetrical, perfectly balanced on the left and right. Other distributions are unbalanced. We say they are “skewed” and have “tails.

khanAcademyContent.name: Clusters, gaps, peaks, & outliers
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice some nifty new vocab for describing data distributions.

data.description: Recognize that a measure of center for a numerical data set summarizes all of its values with a single number, while a measure of variation describes how its values vary with a single number.

khanAcademyContent.name: Reading dot plots & frequency tables
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice reading basic dot plots and frequency tables.

khanAcademyContent.name: Estimate center using dot plots
khanAcademyContent.description: Use dot plots to estimate the "typical" amount shown.

khanAcademyContent.name: Effects of shifting, adding, & removing a data point
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice figuring out how the mean and median are affected when a data point is added to, taken from, or shifted within a data set.

khanAcademyContent.name: Data set warm-up
khanAcademyContent.description: Begin your journey into the world of statistics with some warm-up questions about data sets.

children.name: Summarize And Describe Distributions.

data.description: Display numerical data in plots on a number line, including dot plots, histograms, and box plots.

khanAcademyContent.name: Read histograms
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice reading and interpreting histograms.

khanAcademyContent.name: Reading box plots
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice reading information presented in box plots.

khanAcademyContent.name: Calculating the median: data displays
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice computing the median of data sets presented in a variety of formats, such as frequency tables and dot plots.

khanAcademyContent.name: Creating frequency tables
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice creating frequency tables from small data sets.

khanAcademyContent.name: Calculating the mean: data displays
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice computing the mean of data sets presented in a variety of formats, such as frequency tables and dot plots.

khanAcademyContent.name: Creating dot plots
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice creating dot plots. Dot plots are very similar to frequency tables, but they make it easier to see the data.

khanAcademyContent.name: Estimate center using dot plots
khanAcademyContent.description: Use dot plots to estimate the "typical" amount shown.

khanAcademyContent.name: Creating box plots
khanAcademyContent.description: More practice making box plots to summarize data sets.

khanAcademyContent.name: Reading dot plots & frequency tables
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice reading basic dot plots and frequency tables.

khanAcademyContent.name: Comparing data displays
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice interpreting and comparing dot plots, histograms, and box plots.

khanAcademyContent.name: Create histograms
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice creating histograms.

khanAcademyContent.name: Estimate center using histograms
khanAcademyContent.description: Use histograms to estimate the "typical" amount shown.

data.description: Reporting the number of observations.
Describing the nature of the attribute under investigation, including how it was measured and its units of measurement.

Giving quantitative measures of center (median and/or mean) and variability (interquartile range and/or mean absolute deviation), as well as describing any overall pattern and any striking deviations from the overall pattern with reference to the context in which the data were gathered.
Relating the choice of measures of center and variability to the shape of the data distribution and the context in which the data were gathered.
Summarize numerical data sets in relation to their context, such as by:

khanAcademyContent.name: Data set warm-up
khanAcademyContent.description: Begin your journey into the world of statistics with some warm-up questions about data sets.

khanAcademyContent.name: Interpreting quartiles
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice understanding the meaning of quartiles of data sets.

khanAcademyContent.name: Calculating the mean
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice calculating the mean (average) of a data set. The mean gives us a sense of the middle, or center, of the data.

khanAcademyContent.name: Reading box plots
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice reading information presented in box plots.

khanAcademyContent.name: Calculating the mean: data displays
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice computing the mean of data sets presented in a variety of formats, such as frequency tables and dot plots.

khanAcademyContent.name: Effects of shifting, adding, & removing a data point
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice figuring out how the mean and median are affected when a data point is added to, taken from, or shifted within a data set.

khanAcademyContent.name: Read histograms
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice reading and interpreting histograms.

khanAcademyContent.name: Comparing data displays
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice interpreting and comparing dot plots, histograms, and box plots.

khanAcademyContent.name: Estimate center using histograms
khanAcademyContent.description: Use histograms to estimate the "typical" amount shown.

khanAcademyContent.name: Reading dot plots & frequency tables
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice reading basic dot plots and frequency tables.

khanAcademyContent.name: Median & range puzzlers
khanAcademyContent.description: These conceptual problems really make you think! Getting through this exercise will deepen your understanding of median, range, and data sets in general.

khanAcademyContent.name: Interquartile range (IQR)
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice finding the interquartile range (IQR) of a data set.

khanAcademyContent.name: Missing value given the mean
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice solving some more challenging problems where you are given the mean and asked to find a missing piece of data from the original data set.

khanAcademyContent.name: Estimate center using dot plots
khanAcademyContent.description: Use dot plots to estimate the "typical" amount shown.

khanAcademyContent.name: Calculating the median: data displays
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice computing the median of data sets presented in a variety of formats, such as frequency tables and dot plots.

khanAcademyContent.name: Calculating the median
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice finding the median of a data set. Like the mean, the median gives us a sense of the middle, or center, of the data.

children.name: Expressions And Equations
Use Properties Of Operations To Generate Equivalent Expressions.

data.description: Apply properties of operations as strategies to add, subtract, factor, and expand linear expressions with rational coefficients.

khanAcademyContent.name: Distributive property with variables (negative numbers)
khanAcademyContent.description: Factor and expand expressions like -3x-9 by applying the distributive property.  Expressions include variables and negative numbers.

khanAcademyContent.name: Combining like terms with negative coefficients & distribution
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice combining like terms using the distributive property. These problems involve adding and subtracting negative numbers.

khanAcademyContent.name: Combining like terms with rational coefficients
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice combining like terms for expressions that have rational coefficients. This requires adding and subtracting fractions.

khanAcademyContent.name: Equivalent expressions: negative numbers & distribution
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice figuring out which expressions are equivalent by applying your knowledge of negative numbers and the distributive property.

khanAcademyContent.name: Combining like terms with negative coefficients
khanAcademyContent.description: Simplify algebraic expressions by combining like terms. Coefficients on some terms are negative.

data.description: Understand that rewriting an expression in different forms in a problem context can shed light on the problem and how the quantities in it are related. For example, a + 0.05a = 1.05a means that “increase by 5%” is the same as “multiply by 1.05.”

khanAcademyContent.name: Interpreting linear expressions
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice interpreting linear expressions

khanAcademyContent.name: Writing expressions word problems
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice writing slightly more complex algebraic expressions to model real-world situations.

children.name: Solve Real-Life And Mathematical Problems Using Numerical And Algebraic Expressions And Equations.

data.description: Solve multi-step real-life and mathematical problems posed with positive and negative rational numbers in any form (whole numbers, fractions, and decimals), using tools strategically. Apply properties of operations to calculate with numbers in any form; convert between forms as appropriate; and assess the reasonableness of answers using mental computation and estimation strategies. For example: If a woman making $25 an hour gets a 10% raise, she will make an additional 1/10 of her salary an hour, or $2.50, for a new salary of $27.50. If you want to place a towel bar 9 3/4 inches long in the center of a door that is 27 1/2 inches wide, you will need to place the bar about 9 inches from each edge; this estimate can be used as a check on the exact computation.

khanAcademyContent.name: Adding & subtracting rational numbers
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice adding and subtracting negative fractions, decimals, and percents.

khanAcademyContent.name: Rewriting decimals as fractions challenge
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice rewriting decimals as fractions. These problems use decimals with up to four decimal places.

khanAcademyContent.name: Rational number word problems
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice solving multi-step word problems. The numbers in these problems may be fractions, decimals, and percents.

data.description: Solve word problems leading to equations of the form px + q = r and p(x + q) = r, where p, q, and r are specific rational numbers. Solve equations of these forms fluently. Compare an algebraic solution to an arithmetic solution, identifying the sequence of the operations used in each approach. For example, the perimeter of a rectangle is 54 cm. Its length is 6 cm. What is its width?

Solve word problems leading to inequalities of the form px + q > r or px + q < r, where p, q, and r are specific rational numbers. Graph the solution set of the inequality and interpret it in the context of the problem. For example: As a salesperson, you are paid $50 per week plus $3 per sale. This week you want your pay to be at least $100. Write an inequality for the number of sales you need to make, and describe the solutions.
Use variables to represent quantities in a real-world or mathematical problem, and construct simple equations and inequalities to solve problems by reasoning about the quantities.

khanAcademyContent.name: Two-step equations word problems
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice writing equations to model and solve real-world situations.

khanAcademyContent.name: Inequality from graph
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice writing equations of inequalities graphed on number lines.

khanAcademyContent.name: Find the mistake: two-step equations
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice spotting the mistake in someone else's work as they attempt to solve two-step equations.

khanAcademyContent.name: One-step inequalities
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice solving inequalities in one step.

khanAcademyContent.name: Two-step inequality word problems
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice constructing, interpreting, and solving linear inequalities that model real-world situations.

khanAcademyContent.name: Two-step inequalities
khanAcademyContent.description: Solve inequalities that take two steps to solve. For example, solve 3x + 2 > 5.

khanAcademyContent.name: Two-step equations
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice solving equations that take two steps to solve. For example, solve  -16 = x/4 + 2.

khanAcademyContent.name: Two-step equations with decimals and fractions
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice solving equations that take two steps to solve. These problems involve arithmetic with fractions and decimals.

khanAcademyContent.name: Interpret two-step equation word problems
khanAcademyContent.description: Determine what terms and variables in two-step equations represent in a real-world context.

khanAcademyContent.name: Plotting inequalities
khanAcademyContent.description: Create  number line graphs of inequalities.

children.name: Geometry
Draw, Construct, And Describe Geometrical Figures And Describe The Relationships Between Them.

data.description: Solve problems involving scale drawings of geometric figures, including computing actual lengths and areas from a scale drawing and reproducing a scale drawing at a different scale.

khanAcademyContent.name: Interpret scale factor in scale drawings
Scale drawings
khanAcademyContent.description: Find a missing side length in a scale drawing when given either a set of corresponding side lengths or one side length and the scale factor.

khanAcademyContent.name: Construct scale drawings
khanAcademyContent.description: An urban planner needs your help in creating a scale drawing. Let's use our knowledge about scale factor, length, and area to assist.

khanAcademyContent.name: Explore scale copies
khanAcademyContent.description: Visually identify scaled copies of a figure.

khanAcademyContent.name: Corresponding sides and points
khanAcademyContent.description: Identify corresponding sides and points in scale copies of figures.

khanAcademyContent.name: Relate scale drawings to area
khanAcademyContent.description: Understand how creating a scale copy of a figure affects the area of the figure.

khanAcademyContent.name: Identify scale factor in scale drawings
khanAcademyContent.description: Identify scale factor in scale copies of figures.

khanAcademyContent.name: Identify scale copies
khanAcademyContent.description: Determine if one polygon is a scale copy of another.

data.description: Draw (freehand, with ruler and protractor, and with technology) geometric shapes with given conditions. Focus on constructing triangles from three measures of angles or sides, noticing when the conditions determine a unique triangle, more than one triangle, or no triangle.

khanAcademyContent.name: Triangle side length rules
khanAcademyContent.description: Given the lengths of two sides of a triangle, what can we say about the third side?

khanAcademyContent.name: Constructing triangles
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice constructing triangles.

data.description: Describe the two-dimensional figures that result from slicing three- dimensional figures, as in plane sections of right rectangular prisms and right rectangular pyramids.

khanAcademyContent.name: Cross sections of 3D objects (basic)
khanAcademyContent.description: Match 3D objects with their 2D cross-sections.

children.name: Solve Real-Life And Mathematical Problems Involving Angle Measure, Area, Surface Area, And Volume.

data.description: Know the formulas for the area and circumference of a circle and use them to solve problems; give an informal derivation of the relationship between the circumference and area of a circle.

khanAcademyContent.name: Radius and diameter
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice finding the radius and diameter of a circle using both vocabulary and visuals.

khanAcademyContent.name: Area of a circle
khanAcademyContent.description: Find the area of a circle given its radius, diameter, or circumference.

khanAcademyContent.name: Circumference and rotations
khanAcademyContent.description: Determine distance or number of rotations when given circumference, radius, or diameter of a circle.

khanAcademyContent.name: Circumference of parts of circles
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice finding the  circumference of part of a circle.

khanAcademyContent.name: Area and circumference of circles challenge
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice interesting area and circumference problems.

khanAcademyContent.name: Area of parts of circles
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice finding the area of part of a circle.

khanAcademyContent.name: Circumference of a circle
khanAcademyContent.description: Find the circumference of a circle when given either the radius or diameter.  Find the radius or diameter of a circle when given the circumference.

data.description: Use facts about supplementary, complementary, vertical, and adjacent angles in a multi-step problem to write and solve simple equations for an unknown angle in a figure.

khanAcademyContent.name: Vertical angles
khanAcademyContent.description: Use your knowledge about vertical angles to find missing angle measures.

khanAcademyContent.name: Complementary and supplementary angles (no visual)
khanAcademyContent.description: Use complementary and supplementary angles to solve for a missing angle measure.

khanAcademyContent.name: Identifying supplementary, complementary, and vertical angles
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice telling whether two angles are supplementary, complementary, or vertical.

khanAcademyContent.name: Unknown angle problems (with algebra)
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice setting up algebraic equations to solve unknown angle problems.

khanAcademyContent.name: Create equations to solve for missing angles
khanAcademyContent.description: Use understanding of vertical, complementary, and supplementary angles to set up an appropriate equation to solve for a missing angle measure.

khanAcademyContent.name: Finding missing angles
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice using knowledge of vertical, complementary, and supplementary angles to find a missing angle.

khanAcademyContent.name: Complementary and supplementary angles (visual)
khanAcademyContent.description: Use your knowledge about complementary and supplementary angles to find missing angles.

khanAcademyContent.name: Finding angle measures between intersecting lines
khanAcademyContent.description: Use your knowledge about angles to find missing angle measures in various situations.

data.description: Solve real-world and mathematical problems involving area, volume and surface area of two- and three-dimensional objects composed of triangles, quadrilaterals, polygons, cubes, and right prisms.

khanAcademyContent.name: Shaded areas
khanAcademyContent.description: Find the areas of shaded regions which are combinations of squares, triangles, and circles.

khanAcademyContent.name: Volume and surface area word problems
khanAcademyContent.description: Solve word problems involving volume and surface area involving 3D shapes, including composite figures.

children.name: The Number System
Apply And Extend Previous Understandings Of Operations With Fractions To Add, Subtract, Multiply, And Divide Rational Numbers.

data.description: Describe situations in which opposite quantities combine to make 0. For example, a hydrogen atom has 0 charge because its two constituents are oppositely charged.

Understand p + q as the number located a distance |q| from p, in the positive or negative direction depending on whether q is positive or negative. Show that a number and its opposite have a sum of 0 (are additive inverses). Interpret sums of rational numbers by describing real-world contexts.

Understand subtraction of rational numbers as adding the additive inverse, p – q = p + (–q). Show that the distance between two rational numbers on the number line is the absolute value of their difference, and apply this principle in real-world contexts.
Apply properties of operations as strategies to add and subtract rational numbers.
Apply and extend previous understandings of addition and subtraction to add and subtract rational numbers; represent addition and subtraction on a horizontal or vertical number line diagram.

khanAcademyContent.name: Order of operations with negative numbers
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice evaluating expressions using the order of operations. Numbers used in these problems may be negative.

khanAcademyContent.name: Equivalent expressions with negative numbers
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice identifying equivalent expressions involving the addition and subtraction of negative numbers.

khanAcademyContent.name: Ordering negative number expressions
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice solving challenging negative number addition and subtraction problems. Number line models, variables, and absolute value come together to push your knowledge of negative numbers even deeper (maybe even below zero!).

khanAcademyContent.name: Adding & subtracting rational numbers
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice adding and subtracting negative fractions, decimals, and percents.

khanAcademyContent.name: Subtracting negative numbers
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice subtracting positive and negative single-digit numbers.

khanAcademyContent.name: Adding & subtracting negative fractions
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice adding and subtracting positive and negative fractions.

khanAcademyContent.name: Missing numbers on the number line
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice more challenging problems where you identify positive and negative integers on a number line that doesn't have zero labeled.

khanAcademyContent.name: Equivalent expressions with negative numbers and variables
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice identifying equivalent expressions involving the addition and subtraction of negative numbers and variables.

khanAcademyContent.name: Interpreting negative number statements
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice matching addition and subtraction equations to real-world scenarios.

khanAcademyContent.name: Signs of sums
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice determining whether the sum of two numbers is positive, negative, or zero.

khanAcademyContent.name: Negative number addition and subtraction: word problems
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice solving word problems with negative numbers.

khanAcademyContent.name: Understand subtraction as adding the opposite
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice rewriting subtraction problems as equivalent addition problems. For example, 2-9=2+(-9).

khanAcademyContent.name: Substitution with negative numbers
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice plugging in values to evaluate negative number addition and subtraction expressions.

khanAcademyContent.name: Absolute value to find distance
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice taking the absolute value of the difference of two numbers to find the distance between those numbers. Apply this principle to solve word problems.

khanAcademyContent.name: Interpret negative number addition and subtraction expressions
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice working through addition and subtraction problems using the number line.

khanAcademyContent.name: Number equations & number lines
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice writing addition and subtraction equations to match number line diagrams.

khanAcademyContent.name: Absolute value to find distance challenge
khanAcademyContent.description: Solve conceptually challenging absolute value problems. In order to succeed at these problems, you'll need to remember that the absolute value of the difference of two numbers is the distance between those numbers.

khanAcademyContent.name: Addition & subtraction: find the missing value
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice finding the missing value in an addition or subtraction equation involving negative numbers.

khanAcademyContent.name: Adding negative numbers on the number line
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice matching number line diagrams to addition expressions involving negative numbers.

khanAcademyContent.name: Adding negative numbers
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice adding positive and negative single-digit numbers.

khanAcademyContent.name: Adding & subtracting negative numbers
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice solving addition and subtraction problems with integers (positive and negative numbers).

data.description: Understand that multiplication is extended from fractions to rational numbers by requiring that operations continue to satisfy the properties of operations, particularly the distributive property, leading to products such as (–1)(–1) = 1 and the rules for multiplying signed numbers. Interpret products of rational numbers by describing real-world contexts.

Understand that integers can be divided, provided that the divisor is not zero, and every quotient of integers (with non-zero divisor) is a rational number. If p and q are integers, then –(p/q) = (–p)/q = p/(–q). Interpret quotients of rational numbers by describing real- world contexts.
Apply properties of operations as strategies to multiply and divide rational numbers.
Convert a rational number to a decimal using long division; know that the decimal form of a rational number terminates in 0s or eventually repeats.
Apply and extend previous understandings of multiplication and division and of fractions to multiply and divide rational numbers.

khanAcademyContent.name: Converting fractions to decimals
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice converting a fraction to a decimal.   Solutions include repeating decimals.

khanAcademyContent.name: Simplify complex fractions
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice simplifying complex fractions.

khanAcademyContent.name: Order of operations with negative numbers
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice evaluating expressions using the order of operations. Numbers used in these problems may be negative.

khanAcademyContent.name: Signs of expressions
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice finding the signs of the answers to multiplication and division problems with positive and negative numbers.

khanAcademyContent.name: Dividing positive and negative fractions
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice dividing fractions. Fractions in these problems may be positive or negative.

khanAcademyContent.name: Negative signs in fractions
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice rewriting fractions with positive and negative denominators.

khanAcademyContent.name: Order rational numbers
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice comparing decimals, percents, fractions, and mixed numbers.

khanAcademyContent.name: Multiplying negative numbers
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice multiplying integers.

khanAcademyContent.name: Multiplying & dividing negative numbers word problems
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice matching situations to multiplication and division expressions and equations.

khanAcademyContent.name: Dividing by zero
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice identifying when a quotient is undefined because of division by zero.

khanAcademyContent.name: Multiplying positive and negative fractions
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice multiplying fractions. Fractions in these problems may be positive or negative.

khanAcademyContent.name: Dividing mixed numbers with negatives
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice dividing mixed numbers. Numbers in these problems may be positive or negative.

khanAcademyContent.name: Dividing negative numbers
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice dividing integers.

khanAcademyContent.name: Equivalent expressions with negative numbers (multiplication and division)
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice finding equivalent multiplication and division expressions. Numbers in these problems may be negative.

data.description:
Solve real-world and mathematical problems involving the four operations with rational numbers.*

*Computations with rational numbers extend the rules for manipulating fractions to complex fractions.

khanAcademyContent.name: Interpreting negative number statements
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice matching addition and subtraction equations to real-world scenarios.

khanAcademyContent.name: Simplify complex fractions
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice simplifying complex fractions.

khanAcademyContent.name: Negative number addition and subtraction: word problems
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice solving word problems with negative numbers.

children.name: Ratios And Proportional Relationships
Analyze Proportional Relationships And Use Them To Solve Real-World And Mathematical Problems.

data.description: Compute unit rates associated with ratios of fractions, including ratios of lengths, areas and other quantities measured in like or different units. For example, if a person walks 1/2 mile in each 1/4 hour, compute the unit rate as the complex fraction 1/2/1/4 miles per hour, equivalently 2 miles per hour.

khanAcademyContent.name: Rates with fractions
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice computing rates associated with ratios of fractions or decimals.

data.description: Decide whether two quantities are in a proportional relationship, e.g., by testing for equivalent ratios in a table or graphing on a coordinate plane and observing whether the graph is a straight line through the origin.
Identify the constant of proportionality (unit rate) in tables, graphs, equations, diagrams, and verbal descriptions of proportional relationships.

Represent proportional relationships by equations. For example, if total cost t is proportional to the number n of items purchased at a constant price p, the relationship between the total cost and the number of items can be expressed as t = pn.
Explain what a point (x, y) on the graph of a proportional relationship means in terms of the situation, with special attention to the points (0, 0) and (1, r) where r is the unit rate.
Recognize and represent proportional relationships between quantities.

khanAcademyContent.name: Solving proportions
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice solving basic proportions.

khanAcademyContent.name: Interpret constants of proportionality
khanAcademyContent.description: Interpret the meaning of constants of proportionality in tables, equations, contexts, and diagrams.

khanAcademyContent.name: Interpret constant of proportionality in graphs
khanAcademyContent.description: Interpret the meaning of constants of proportionality in graphs.

khanAcademyContent.name: Writing proportional equations
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice writing equations to describe proportional relationships.

khanAcademyContent.name: Constant of proportionality from equations
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice identifying the constant of proportionality from equations.

khanAcademyContent.name: Writing proportions
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice writing proportions to describe real-world situations.

khanAcademyContent.name: Compare constants of proportionality
khanAcademyContent.description: Identify and compare constants of proportionality in graphs, tables, equations, contexts, and diagrams.

khanAcademyContent.name: Proportional relationships
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice telling whether or not the relationship between two quantities is proportional by reasoning about equivalent ratios.

khanAcademyContent.name: Constant of proportionality from tables
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice identifying the constant of proportionality from tables.

khanAcademyContent.name: Identify proportional relationships
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice telling whether or not the relationship between two quantities is proportional by looking at a table  of the relationship.

khanAcademyContent.name: Constant of proportionality from graphs
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice identifying the constant of proportionality from graphs.

khanAcademyContent.name: Identify proportional relationships from graphs
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice telling whether or not the relationship between two quantities is proportional by looking at a graph of the relationship.

khanAcademyContent.name: Interpreting graphs of proportional relationships
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice reading and analyzing graphs of proportional relationships.

khanAcademyContent.name: Constant of proportionality from tables (with equations)
khanAcademyContent.description: Use the equation, y=rx to identify r from a table of values.

data.description: Use proportional relationships to solve multistep ratio and percent problems. Examples: simple interest, tax, markups and markdowns, gratuities and commissions, fees, percent increase and decrease, percent error.

khanAcademyContent.name: Discount, markup, and commission word problems
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice solving percent word problems involving price discounts, price markups, and commission fees.

khanAcademyContent.name: Proportion word problems
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice setting up and solving proportions to solve word problems.

khanAcademyContent.name: Percent problems
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice solving word problems involving percents, including percents comparisons and percent of change,

khanAcademyContent.name: Tax and tip word problems
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice solving percent word problems involving tax and tip.

khanAcademyContent.name: Equivalent expressions with percent problems
khanAcademyContent.description: Create expressions with fractions and decimals to solve real world percent word problems.

children.name: Statistics And Probability
Use Random Sampling To Draw Inferences About A Population.

data.description: Understand that statistics can be used to gain information about a population by examining a sample of the population; generalizations about a population from a sample are valid only if the sample is representative of that population. Understand that random sampling tends to produce representative samples and support valid inferences.

khanAcademyContent.name: Making inferences from random samples
khanAcademyContent.description: Given a random sample, practice figuring out what can we reasonably infer about the entire population?

khanAcademyContent.name: Valid claims
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice figuring out whether we took a random sample and whether we're able to draw valid conclusions from our data.

data.description: Use data from a random sample to draw inferences about a population with an unknown characteristic of interest. Generate multiple samples (or simulated samples) of the same size to gauge the variation in estimates or predictions. For example, estimate the mean word length in a book by randomly sampling words from the book; predict the winner of a school election based on randomly sampled survey data. Gauge how far off the estimate or prediction might be.

khanAcademyContent.name: Making inferences from random samples
khanAcademyContent.description: Given a random sample, practice figuring out what can we reasonably infer about the entire population?

khanAcademyContent.name: Valid claims
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice figuring out whether we took a random sample and whether we're able to draw valid conclusions from our data.

children.name: Draw Informal Comparative Inferences About Two Populations.

data.description: Informally assess the degree of visual overlap of two numerical data distributions with similar variabilities, measuring the difference between the centers by expressing it as a multiple of a measure of variability. For example, the mean height of players on the basketball team is 10 cm greater than the mean height of players on the soccer team, about twice the variability (mean absolute deviation) on either team; on a dot plot, the separation between the two distributions of heights is noticeable.

khanAcademyContent.name: Comparing distributions
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice comparing distributions that are presented in dot plots, histograms, and box plots.

data.description: Use measures of center and measures of variability for numerical data from random samples to draw informal comparative inferences about two populations. For example, decide whether the words in a chapter of a seventh-grade science book are generally longer than the words in a chapter of a fourth-grade science book.

khanAcademyContent.name: Comparing distributions
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice comparing distributions that are presented in dot plots, histograms, and box plots.

children.name: Investigate Chance Processes And Develop, Use, And Evaluate Probability Models.

data.description: Understand that the probability of a chance event is a number between 0 and 1 that expresses the likelihood of the event occurring. Larger numbers indicate greater likelihood. A probability near 0 indicates an unlikely event, a probability around 1/2 indicates an event that is neither unlikely nor likely, and a probability near 1 indicates a likely event.

khanAcademyContent.name: Probability models
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice creating probability models and understand what makes a valid probability model.

data.description: Approximate the probability of a chance event by collecting data on the chance process that produces it and observing its long-run relative frequency, and predict the approximate relative frequency given the probability. For example, when rolling a number cube 600 times, predict that a 3 or 6 would be rolled roughly 200 times, but probably not exactly 200 times.

khanAcademyContent.name: Experimental probability
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice making reasonable estimates of the likelihood of future events based on past experience.

khanAcademyContent.name: Probability models
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice creating probability models and understand what makes a valid probability model.

khanAcademyContent.name: Making predictions with probability
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice predicting the number of times a certain event will happen.

data.description: Develop a uniform probability model by assigning equal probability to all outcomes, and use the model to determine probabilities of events. For example, if a student is selected at random from a class, find the probability that Jane will be selected and the probability that a girl will be selected.

Develop a probability model (which may not be uniform) by observing frequencies in data generated from a chance process. For example, find the approximate probability that a spinning penny will land heads up or that a tossed paper cup will land open-end down. Do the outcomes for the spinning penny appear to be equally likely based on the observed frequencies?

Develop a probability model and use it to find probabilities of events. Compare probabilities from a model to observed frequencies; if the agreement is not good, explain possible sources of the discrepancy.

khanAcademyContent.name: Simple probability
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice finding probabilities of events, such as rolling dice, drawing marbles out of a bag, and spinning spinners.

khanAcademyContent.name: Probability models
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice creating probability models and understand what makes a valid probability model.

khanAcademyContent.name: Making predictions with probability
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice predicting the number of times a certain event will happen.

data.description: Understand that, just as with simple events, the probability of a compound event is the fraction of outcomes in the sample space for which the compound event occurs.

Represent sample spaces for compound events using methods such as organized lists, tables and tree diagrams. For an event described in everyday language (e.g., “rolling double sixes”), identify the outcomes in the sample space which compose the event.

Design and use a simulation to generate frequencies for compound events. For example, use random digits as a simulation tool to approximate the answer to the question: If 40% of donors have type A blood, what is the probability that it will take at least 4 donors to find one with type A blood?
Find probabilities of compound events using organized lists, tables, tree diagrams, and simulation.

khanAcademyContent.name: The counting principle
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice counting possible outcomes in a variety of situations. These problems cover everything from counting the number of ways to get dressed in the morning to counting the number of ways to build a custom pizza.

khanAcademyContent.name: Sample spaces for compound events
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice checking if sample space diagrams match a compound event.

khanAcademyContent.name: Probabilities of compound events
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice using sample space diagrams to find probabilities.

children.name: Expressions And Equations
Work With Radicals And Integer Exponents.

data.description: Know and apply the properties of integer exponents to generate equivalent numerical expressions. For example, 32 × 3–5 = 3–3 = 1/33 = 1/27.

khanAcademyContent.name: Divide powers
khanAcademyContent.description: Rewrite quotients of powers with the same base. For example, (x⁵)/(x²) can be written as x³.

khanAcademyContent.name: Multiply powers
khanAcademyContent.description: Rewrite products of powers with the same base. For example, x²⋅x⁵ can be written as x⁷.

khanAcademyContent.name: Exponents with integer bases
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice raising positive and negative numbers (integers only) to whole number powers. Watch out for mischievous negative signs that aren't really part of the base!

khanAcademyContent.name: Powers of products & quotients
khanAcademyContent.description: Rewrite powers of products and quotients. For example, (3⁵⋅x³)² can be written as 3¹⁰⋅x⁶.

khanAcademyContent.name: Powers of products & quotients (integer exponents)
khanAcademyContent.description: Rewrite powers where the base includes more powers, and the exponents may be negative.

khanAcademyContent.name: Exponents with negative fractional bases
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice raising fractions to whole number powers. Fractions in these problems may be positive or negative.

khanAcademyContent.name: Signs of expressions challenge
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice finding the signs of the answers to complex multiplication and division problems involving exponents.

khanAcademyContent.name: Negative exponents
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice computing numbers raised to positive and negative exponents. Bases may be fractions.

khanAcademyContent.name: Multiply & divide powers (integer exponents)
khanAcademyContent.description: Rewrite products or quotients of powers, including negative powers.

khanAcademyContent.name: Powers of products & quotients (structured practice)
khanAcademyContent.description: Rewrite expressions that involve powers of products and quotients. Expressions are in ascending difficulty.

khanAcademyContent.name: Properties of exponents challenge (integer exponents)
khanAcademyContent.description: A quiz that cover all exponent properties using integer exponents.

khanAcademyContent.name: Powers of powers
khanAcademyContent.description: Rewrite powers of powers. For example, (x²)⁵ can be written as x¹⁰.

data.description: Use square root and cube root symbols to represent solutions to equations of the form x2 = p and x3 = p, where p is a positive rational number. Evaluate square roots of small perfect squares and cube roots of small perfect cubes. Know that √2 is irrational.

khanAcademyContent.name: Equations with square roots: decimals & fractions
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice solving equations by squaring or finding square root of decimals and fractions.

khanAcademyContent.name: Square roots
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice finding the square root of a perfect square positive integer.

khanAcademyContent.name: Cube roots
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice finding the cube root of a perfect cube positive integer.

khanAcademyContent.name: Square and cube challenge
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice solving problems using your knowledge of square and cube roots.

khanAcademyContent.name: Roots of decimals & fractions
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice taking square roots of decimals and fractions.

khanAcademyContent.name: Equations with square roots & cube roots
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice solving equations by squaring or cubing both sides.

data.description: Use numbers expressed in the form of a single digit times an integer power of 10 to estimate very large or very small quantities, and to express how many times as much one is than the other. For example, estimate the population of the United States as 3 × 108 and the population of the world as 7 × 109, and determine that the world population is more than 20 times larger.

khanAcademyContent.name: Scientific notation
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice expressing numbers in scientific notation.

khanAcademyContent.name: Multiplication and division with powers of ten
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice solving multiplication and division problems that involve powers of ten.

khanAcademyContent.name: Approximating with powers of 10
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice comparing two real-world quantities by approximating them with powers of 10.

data.description: Perform operations with numbers expressed in scientific notation, including problems where both decimal and scientific notation are used. Use scientific notation and choose units of appropriate size for measurements of very large or very small quantities (e.g., use millimeters per year for seafloor spreading). Interpret scientific notation that has been generated by technology.

khanAcademyContent.name: Multiplication and division with powers of ten
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice solving multiplication and division problems that involve powers of ten.

khanAcademyContent.name: Scientific notation word problems
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice solving addition, subtraction, multiplication, and division problems involving scientific notation.

khanAcademyContent.name: Approximating with powers of 10
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice comparing two real-world quantities by approximating them with powers of 10.

khanAcademyContent.name: Adding & subtracting in scientific notation
khanAcademyContent.description: Given two numbers in scientific notation, practice adding and subtracting them.

khanAcademyContent.name: Multiplying & dividing in scientific notation
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice expressing products and quotients in scientific notation.

children.name: Understand The Connections Between Proportional Relationships, Lines, And Linear Equations.

data.description: Graph proportional relationships, interpreting the unit rate as the slope of the graph. Compare two different proportional relationships represented in different ways. For example, compare a distance-time graph to a distance-time equation to determine which of two moving objects has greater speed.

khanAcademyContent.name: Rates & proportional relationships
khanAcademyContent.description: A variety of questions about rates and proportional relationships involving graphs, tables, and equations.

data.description: Use similar triangles to explain why the slope m is the same between any two distinct points on a non-vertical line in the coordinate plane; derive the equation y = mx for a line through the origin and the equation y = mx + b for a line intercepting the vertical axis at b.

children.name: Analyze And Solve Linear Equations And Pairs Of Simultaneous Linear Equations.

data.description: Give examples of linear equations in one variable with one solution, infinitely many solutions, or no solutions. Show which of these possibilities is the case by successively transforming the given equation into simpler forms, until an equivalent equation of the form x = a, a = a, or a = b results (where a and b are different numbers).
Solve linear equations with rational number coefficients, including equations whose solutions require expanding expressions using the distributive property and collecting like terms.
Solve linear equations in one variable.

khanAcademyContent.name: Equations with variables on both sides: decimals & fractions
khanAcademyContent.description: Solve linear equations where the variable appears on both sides of the equation and the coefficients are decimals or fractions.

khanAcademyContent.name: Slope-intercept from two points
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice finding the equation of a line passing through two points

khanAcademyContent.name: Number of solutions to equations
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice telling whether an equation has one, zero, or infinite solutions. For example, how many solutions does the equation 8(3x+10)=28x-14-4x have?

khanAcademyContent.name: Number of solutions to equations challenge
khanAcademyContent.description: Given a linear equation with missing values, determine appropriate values in order to have one, zero, or infinite solutions. For example, complete the equation -11x + 4 = __x + __ so that it has no solutions.

khanAcademyContent.name: Equations with variables on both sides
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice solving one-variable equations like 20 - 7x = 6x - 6, where the variable appears on both sides of the equals sign.

khanAcademyContent.name: Equations with parentheses: decimals & fractions
khanAcademyContent.description: Solve linear equations that contain expressions with parentheses and the coefficients are rational numbers.

khanAcademyContent.name: Sums of consecutive integers
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice finding the nth number in a sequence of consecutive numbers based on the sum.

khanAcademyContent.name: Equations with parentheses
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice solving equations with parentheses using the distributive property.

khanAcademyContent.name: Intercepts from an equation
khanAcademyContent.description: Solve linear equations for the x-intercept and y-intercept

data.description: Understand that solutions to a system of two linear equations in two variables correspond to points of intersection of their graphs, because points of intersection satisfy both equations simultaneously.

Solve systems of two linear equations in two variables algebraically, and estimate solutions by graphing the equations. Solve simple cases by inspection. For example, 3x + 2y = 5 and 3x + 2y = 6 have no solution because 3x + 2y cannot simultaneously be 5 and 6.

Solve real-world and mathematical problems leading to two linear equations in two variables. For example, given coordinates for two pairs of points, determine whether the line through the first pair of points intersects the line through the second pair.
Analyze and solve pairs of simultaneous linear equations.

khanAcademyContent.name: Number of solutions to a system of equations graphically
khanAcademyContent.description: Determine the number of solutions of a given system of equations by considering its graph.

khanAcademyContent.name: Age word problems
khanAcademyContent.description: Solve age word problems with a system of equations.

khanAcademyContent.name: Systems of equations with graphing
khanAcademyContent.description: Graph a system of equations in slope-intercept or standard form, and find their solution using the graphs.

khanAcademyContent.name: Number of solutions to a system of equations algebraically
khanAcademyContent.description: Determine the number of solutions of a given system of equations by considering its algebraic solution process.

khanAcademyContent.name: Solutions of systems of equations
khanAcademyContent.description: Verify whether a given pair of values is a solution to a system of equations.

khanAcademyContent.name: Systems of equations word problems
khanAcademyContent.description: Solve word problems by modeling them into a system of equations and solving it.

khanAcademyContent.name: Systems of equations with substitution
khanAcademyContent.description: Solve systems of equations where one of the equations is solved for one of the variables.

children.name: Functions
Define, Evaluate, And Compare Functions.

data.description:
Understand that a function is a rule that assigns to each input exactly one output. The graph of a function is the set of ordered pairs consisting of an input and the corresponding output.*

*Function notation is not required in Grade 8.

khanAcademyContent.name: Recognize functions from tables
khanAcademyContent.description: Determine whether a table of values of a relationship represents a function.

khanAcademyContent.name: Recognize functions from graphs
khanAcademyContent.description: Determine whether a given graph represents a function.

khanAcademyContent.name: Linear equations word problems
khanAcademyContent.description: Solve word problems about real world relationships that are given in formulas.

khanAcademyContent.name: Evaluate functions from their graph
khanAcademyContent.description: Evaluate functions for specific inputs given the graph of the function.

khanAcademyContent.name: Evaluate functions
khanAcademyContent.description: Evaluate functions for specific inputs given the formula of the function.

khanAcademyContent.name: Function rules from equations
khanAcademyContent.description: Create functions that match one variable to the other in a two-variable equation.

khanAcademyContent.name: Graph from slope-intercept form
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice drawing the graph of a line given in slope-intercept form. For example, graph y = 3x + 2.

khanAcademyContent.name: Slope-intercept from two points
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice finding the equation of a line passing through two points

khanAcademyContent.name: Complete solutions to 2-variable equations
khanAcademyContent.description: Given the x or y value of a 2-variable equation solution, find the value for the other variable in the solution.

khanAcademyContent.name: Solutions to 2-variable equations
khanAcademyContent.description: Determine which ordered pairs are solutions to equations.

khanAcademyContent.name: Intercepts from a graph
khanAcademyContent.description: Look at the graph of an equation to find x-intercepts and y-intercepts

khanAcademyContent.name: Slope-intercept equation from graph
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice finding the slope-intercept equation of a line from its graph.

data.description: Compare properties of two functions each represented in a different way (algebraically, graphically, numerically in tables, or by verbal descriptions). For example, given a linear function represented by a table of values and a linear function represented by an algebraic expression, determine which function has the greater rate of change.

khanAcademyContent.name: Compare linear functions
khanAcademyContent.description: Compare features of two linear functions represented in different ways.

data.description: Interpret the equation y = mx + b as defining a linear function, whose graph is a straight line; give examples of functions that are not linear. For example, the function A = s2 giving the area of a square as a function of its side length is not linear because its graph contains the points (1,1), (2,4) and (3,9), which are not on a straight line.

khanAcademyContent.name: Slope-intercept equation from graph
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice finding the slope-intercept equation of a line from its graph.

khanAcademyContent.name: Slope-intercept from two points
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice finding the equation of a line passing through two points

khanAcademyContent.name: Graph from slope-intercept form
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice drawing the graph of a line given in slope-intercept form. For example, graph y = 3x + 2.

khanAcademyContent.name: Intercepts from an equation
khanAcademyContent.description: Solve linear equations for the x-intercept and y-intercept

khanAcademyContent.name: Linear & nonlinear functions
khanAcademyContent.description: Determine if a relationship is linear or nonlinear.

children.name: Use Functions To Model Relationships Between Quantities.

data.description: Construct a function to model a linear relationship between two quantities. Determine the rate of change and initial value of the function from a description of a relationship or from two (x, y) values, including reading these from a table or from a graph. Interpret the rate of change and initial value of a linear function in terms of the situation it models, and in terms of its graph or a table of values.

khanAcademyContent.name: Slope from graph
khanAcademyContent.description: Find the slope of a line on the coordinate plane.

khanAcademyContent.name: Slope from two points
khanAcademyContent.description: Find the slope of the line that goes through the two points that are given to you.

khanAcademyContent.name: Slope from equation
khanAcademyContent.description: Find the slopes of lines whose equations are given in various forms. For example, find the slope of 2x+3y=5.

khanAcademyContent.name: Slope-intercept from two points
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice finding the equation of a line passing through two points

khanAcademyContent.name: Slope-intercept equation from graph
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice finding the slope-intercept equation of a line from its graph.

khanAcademyContent.name: Slope-intercept intro
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice your basic understanding of slope-intercept form for linear equations.

data.description: Describe qualitatively the functional relationship between two quantities by analyzing a graph (e.g., where the function is increasing or decreasing, linear or nonlinear). Sketch a graph that exhibits the qualitative features of a function that has been described verbally.

khanAcademyContent.name: Interpreting graphs of functions
khanAcademyContent.description: Interpret the graphs of both linear and nonlinear functions.

children.name: Geometry
Understand Congruence And Similarity Using Physical Models, Transparencies, Or Geometry Software.

data.description: Lines are taken to lines, and line segments to line segments of the same length.
Angles are taken to angles of the same measure.
Parallel lines are taken to parallel lines.
Verify experimentally the properties of rotations, reflections, and translations:

khanAcademyContent.name: Identify transformations
khanAcademyContent.description: Identify the transformation (translation, rotation, reflection, or dilation) that has been applied to a figure.

khanAcademyContent.name: Reflect points
khanAcademyContent.description: Given a point and a definition of a reflection, plot the reflection on a coordinate plane or identify the coordinates of the reflected point.

khanAcademyContent.name: Rigid transformations: preserved properties
khanAcademyContent.description: Identify which properties of shapes remain the same after a rigid transformation (reflection, rotation, translation) has been applied.

khanAcademyContent.name: Find measures using rigid transformations
khanAcademyContent.description: Use your knowledge about the effects of rigid transformations to solve problems about figures and their images under transformations.

khanAcademyContent.name: Translate shapes
khanAcademyContent.description: Given a figure and a definition of a translation, manually draw the image.

khanAcademyContent.name: Determine rotations (basic)
khanAcademyContent.description: Given a figure on the coordinate plane and a center of a rotation, find the angle for the rotation that maps one figure to the other.  Rotations are around the origin and a multiple of 90º.

khanAcademyContent.name: Mapping shapes
khanAcademyContent.description: Map a given shape into another using sequences of rigid transformations (translations, rotations, and/or reflections).

khanAcademyContent.name: Determine translations
khanAcademyContent.description: Given two figures on the coordinate plane, find the formal definition of the translation that takes one figure to another.

khanAcademyContent.name: Reflect shapes
khanAcademyContent.description: Given a figure and a definition of a reflection, manually draw the image.

khanAcademyContent.name: Determine reflections
khanAcademyContent.description: Given a shape and its image under a reflection, determine the line of reflection.

khanAcademyContent.name: Rotate points (basic)
khanAcademyContent.description: Given a point and a definition of a rotation, plot the rotation on a coordinate plane or identify the coordinates of the rotated point.  Rotations are about the origin and multiples of 90º.

data.description: Understand that a two-dimensional figure is congruent to another if the second can be obtained from the first by a sequence of rotations, reflections, and translations; given two congruent figures, describe a sequence that exhibits the congruence between them.

khanAcademyContent.name: Find measures using rigid transformations
khanAcademyContent.description: Use your knowledge about the effects of rigid transformations to solve problems about figures and their images under transformations.

khanAcademyContent.name: Rigid transformations: preserved properties
khanAcademyContent.description: Identify which properties of shapes remain the same after a rigid transformation (reflection, rotation, translation) has been applied.

khanAcademyContent.name: Mapping shapes
khanAcademyContent.description: Map a given shape into another using sequences of rigid transformations (translations, rotations, and/or reflections).

khanAcademyContent.name: Congruence & transformations
khanAcademyContent.description: Given a pair of figures in the coordinate plane, try to map one onto the other and determine whether they are congruent.

data.description: Describe the effect of dilations, translations, rotations, and reflections on two-dimensional figures using coordinates.

khanAcademyContent.name: Determine translations
khanAcademyContent.description: Given two figures on the coordinate plane, find the formal definition of the translation that takes one figure to another.

khanAcademyContent.name: Translate shapes
khanAcademyContent.description: Given a figure and a definition of a translation, manually draw the image.

khanAcademyContent.name: Reflect points
khanAcademyContent.description: Given a point and a definition of a reflection, plot the reflection on a coordinate plane or identify the coordinates of the reflected point.

khanAcademyContent.name: Dilations: scale factor
khanAcademyContent.description: Find both the center and the scale factor of a dilation that maps a given figure to another one.

khanAcademyContent.name: Reflect shapes
khanAcademyContent.description: Given a figure and a definition of a reflection, manually draw the image.

khanAcademyContent.name: Dilate triangles
khanAcademyContent.description: Given a figure and a definition of a dilation, manually draw the image.

khanAcademyContent.name: Determine rotations (basic)
khanAcademyContent.description: Given a figure on the coordinate plane and a center of a rotation, find the angle for the rotation that maps one figure to the other.  Rotations are around the origin and a multiple of 90º.

khanAcademyContent.name: Dilations and properties
khanAcademyContent.description: Given a shape and the dilation that is performed on it, determine which properties are shared by the shape and its image.

khanAcademyContent.name: Determine reflections
khanAcademyContent.description: Given a shape and its image under a reflection, determine the line of reflection.

khanAcademyContent.name: Dilate points
khanAcademyContent.description: Use the interactive transformation tool to perform dilations.

data.description: Understand that a two-dimensional figure is similar to another if the second can be obtained from the first by a sequence of rotations, reflections, translations, and dilations; given two similar two- dimensional figures, describe a sequence that exhibits the similarity between them.

khanAcademyContent.name: Dilate triangles
khanAcademyContent.description: Given a figure and a definition of a dilation, manually draw the image.

khanAcademyContent.name: Dilations and properties
khanAcademyContent.description: Given a shape and the dilation that is performed on it, determine which properties are shared by the shape and its image.

khanAcademyContent.name: Similarity & transformations
khanAcademyContent.description: Given two polygons, try to map one onto the other using angle-preserving transformations, and determine whether they are similar.

khanAcademyContent.name: Dilations: scale factor
khanAcademyContent.description: Find both the center and the scale factor of a dilation that maps a given figure to another one.

data.description: Use informal arguments to establish facts about the angle sum and exterior angle of triangles, about the angles created when parallel lines are cut by a transversal, and the angle-angle criterion for similarity of triangles. For example, arrange three copies of the same triangle so that the sum of the three angles appears to form a line, and give an argument in terms of transversals why this is so.

khanAcademyContent.name: Finding angle measures using triangles
khanAcademyContent.description: Use your knowledge about angles to find missing angle measures in various complex situations.

khanAcademyContent.name: Find angles in triangles
khanAcademyContent.description: Find missing angle measures in triangles using the properties of general triangles, isosceles triangles, and equilateral triangles.

khanAcademyContent.name: Find angles in isosceles triangles
khanAcademyContent.description: Find missing angles in isosceles triangles given just one angle.

khanAcademyContent.name: Angle relationships with parallel lines
khanAcademyContent.description: Find missing angles given two parallel lines and a transversal.

children.name: Understand And Apply The Pythagorean Theorem.

data.description: Explain a proof of the Pythagorean Theorem and its converse.

khanAcademyContent.name: Use area of squares to visualize Pythagorean theorem
khanAcademyContent.description: Explain the Pythagorean theorem and its converse using the area of squares.

data.description: Apply the Pythagorean Theorem to determine unknown side lengths in right triangles in real-world and mathematical problems in two and three dimensions.

khanAcademyContent.name: Use Pythagorean theorem to find isosceles triangle side lengths
khanAcademyContent.description: Find a missing side length on an acute isosceles triangle by using the Pythagorean theorem.

khanAcademyContent.name: Right triangle side lengths
khanAcademyContent.description: Use the Pythagorean theorem to determine if the given side lengths could form a right triangle.

khanAcademyContent.name: Use Pythagorean theorem to find area
khanAcademyContent.description: Find the area of triangles and quadrilaterals by first using the Pythagorean Theorem to find missing side lengths.

khanAcademyContent.name: Pythagorean theorem challenge
khanAcademyContent.description: Solve real-world problems that can be modeled by right triangles, using the Pythagorean Theorem!

khanAcademyContent.name: Use Pythagorean theorem to find perimeter
khanAcademyContent.description: Find the perimeter of triangles and quadrilaterals by first using the Pythagorean Theorem to find missing side lengths.

khanAcademyContent.name: Pythagorean theorem word problems
khanAcademyContent.description: Use the Pythagorean theorem to solve word problems.

khanAcademyContent.name: Use Pythagorean theorem to find right triangle side lengths
khanAcademyContent.description: Find the length of the hypotenuse or a leg of a right triangle using the Pythagorean theorem.

data.description: Apply the Pythagorean Theorem to find the distance between two points in a coordinate system.

khanAcademyContent.name: Distance between two points
khanAcademyContent.description: Use the Pythagorean theorem to find the distance between two points on the coordinate plane.

children.name: Solve Real-World And Mathematical Problems Involving Volume Of Cylinders, Cones, And Spheres.

data.description: Know the formulas for the volumes of cones, cylinders, and spheres and use them to solve real-world and mathematical problems.

khanAcademyContent.name: Volume of cones
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice applying the volume formulas for cones.

khanAcademyContent.name: Volume of cylinders, spheres, and cones word problems
khanAcademyContent.description: Solve word problems involving volume of cylinders, spheres, and cones.

khanAcademyContent.name: Volume of spheres
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice applying the volume formulas for spheres.

khanAcademyContent.name: Volume of cylinders
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice applying the volume formulas for cylinders.

children.name: The Number System
Know That There Are Numbers That Are Not Rational, And Approximate Them By Rational Numbers.

data.description: Know that numbers that are not rational are called irrational. Understand informally that every number has a decimal expansion; for rational numbers show that the decimal expansion repeats eventually, and convert a decimal expansion which repeats eventually into a rational number.

khanAcademyContent.name: Converting multi-digit repeating decimals to fractions
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice converting multi-digit repeating decimals to fractions.

khanAcademyContent.name: Writing fractions as repeating decimals
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice writing fractions as repeating decimals. Get ready to bust out those long division skills!

khanAcademyContent.name: Classify numbers: rational & irrational
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice identifying whether numbers are rational or irrational.

khanAcademyContent.name: Converting repeating decimals to fractions
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice converting 1- and 2-digit repeating decimals to fractions.

khanAcademyContent.name: Classify numbers
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice classifying numbers as whole, integer, rational, and irrational.

data.description: Use rational approximations of irrational numbers to compare the size of irrational numbers, locate them approximately on a number line diagram, and estimate the value of expressions (e.g., √2). For example, by truncating the decimal expansion of √2, show that √2 is between 1 and 2, then between 1.4 and 1.5, and explain how to continue on to get better approximations.

khanAcademyContent.name: Approximating square roots
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice finding the approximate value of square roots by thinking about perfect squares.

khanAcademyContent.name: Comparing irrational numbers
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice comparing irrational numbers without using a calculator.

khanAcademyContent.name: Comparing irrational numbers with a calculator
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice using a calculator to find the approximate decimal values of irrational numbers.

children.name: Statistics And Probability
Investigate Patterns Of Association In Bivariate Data.

data.description: Construct and interpret scatter plots for bivariate measurement data to investigate patterns of association between two quantities. Describe patterns such as clustering, outliers, positive or negative association, linear association, and nonlinear association.

khanAcademyContent.name: Constructing scatter plots
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice plotting points to construct a scatter plot.

khanAcademyContent.name: Describing trends in scatter plots
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice making sense of trends in scatter plots. That is, explain what trends mean in terms of real-world quantities.

khanAcademyContent.name: Making appropriate scatter plots
khanAcademyContent.description: An appropriate scatter plot has the independent variable on the x-axis and the dependent variable on the y-axis. Also, the scale of both axes should be reasonable, making the data as easy to read as possible. In these practice problems, we practice telling good scatter plots from bad ones.

khanAcademyContent.name: Positive and negative linear associations from scatter plots
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice identifying the types of associations shown in scatter plots. Sometimes we see linear associations (positive or negative), sometimes we see non-linear associations (the data seems to follow a curve), and other times we don't see any association at all.

data.description: Know that straight lines are widely used to model relationships between two quantitative variables. For scatter plots that suggest a linear association, informally fit a straight line, and informally assess the model fit by judging the closeness of the data points to the line.

khanAcademyContent.name: Eyeballing the line of best fit
khanAcademyContent.description: Given a random assortment of points, draw a line of best fit through them.

data.description: Use the equation of a linear model to solve problems in the context of bivariate measurement data, interpreting the slope and intercept. For example, in a linear model for a biology experiment, interpret a slope of 1.5 cm/hr as meaning that an additional hour of sunlight each day is associated with an additional 1.5 cm in mature plant height.

khanAcademyContent.name: Interpreting slope and y-intercept for linear models
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice explaining the meaning of slope and y-intercept for lines of best fit on scatter plots.

khanAcademyContent.name: Estimating slope of line of best fit
khanAcademyContent.description: Given a scatter plot, can you estimate the slope of the line of best fit that goes through the data points?

khanAcademyContent.name: Estimating equations of lines of best fit, and using them to make predictions
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice estimating the equation of a line of best fit through data points in a scatter plot. Then, use the equation to make a prediction.

data.description: Understand that patterns of association can also be seen in bivariate categorical data by displaying frequencies and relative frequencies in a two-way table. Construct and interpret a two-way table summarizing data on two categorical variables collected from the same subjects. Use relative frequencies calculated for rows or columns to describe possible association between the two variables. For example, collect data from students in your class on whether or not they have a curfew on school nights and whether or not they have assigned chores at home. Is there evidence that those who have a curfew also tend to have chores?

khanAcademyContent.name: Interpreting two-way tables
khanAcademyContent.description: Do you understand how two-way tables really work? Here's your chance to practice. Go get 'em! You got this!

khanAcademyContent.name: Create two-way relative frequency tables
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice creating two-way relative frequency tables from a two-way frequency table.

khanAcademyContent.name: Read two-way frequency tables
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice interpreting two-way frequency tables. For example, what does the cell in the top left tell you?

khanAcademyContent.name: Create two-way frequency tables
khanAcademyContent.description: Given a Venn diagram or information about a relationship, create a two-way frequency table.

khanAcademyContent.name: Reading two-way relative frequency tables
khanAcademyContent.description: Practice interpreting two-way relative frequency tables
